effector cells.defn: In cellular immunity, B cells and T cells that attack an antigen, either by secreting antibodies that bind to the antigen or by releasing molecules that destroy any cell bearing the antigen.

effector mechanisms.defn: Adaptations that enable an organism to alter its physiological or behavioral state.

effector protein.defn: In cell signaling, a protein responsible for the cellular response to a signal transduction pathway.

efferent.defn: Carrying outward or away from, as in neurons that carry impulses outward from the central to the peripheral nervous system (efferent neurons), or a blood vessel that carries blood away from a structure (efferent arterioles).

egg.defn: In all sexually reproducing organisms, the female gamete; in birds, reptiles, and some other vertebrates, a structure within which early embryonic development occurs.

ejaculatory duct.defn: The duct that carries semen from the seminal vesicle to the urethra.

electrical synapse.defn: A type of synapse at which action potentials spread directly from presynaptic cell to postsynaptic cell.

electrocardiogram.defn: A graphic recording of electrical potentials from the heart.

electrochemical gradient.defn: The concentration gradient of an ion across a membrane plus the voltage difference across that membrane.

electroencephalogram.defn: A graphic recording of electrical potentials from the brain.

electromagnetic radiation.defn: A self-propagating wave that travels though space and has both electrical and magnetic properties.

electron.defn: A subatomic particle outside the nucleus carrying a negative charge and very little mass.

electron shell.defn: The region surrounding the atomic nucleus at a fixed energy level in which electrons orbit.

electronegativity.defn: The tendency of an atom to attract electrons when it occurs as part of a compound.

element.defn: A substance that cannot be converted to a simpler substance by ordinary chemical means.

elicitors.defn: Molecules associated with plant pathogens that attach to specialized receptors in plants to initiate a defensive response.

elongation.defn: (1) In molecular biology, the addition of monomers to make a longer RNA or protein during transcription or translation. (2) Growth of a plant axis or cell primarily in the longitudinal direction.

embolus.defn: A circulating blood clot. Blockage of a blood vessel by an embolus or a bubble of gas is called an embolism.

embryo.defn: A young animal, or young plant sporophyte, while it is still contained within a protective structure such as an egg, uterus, or seed.

embryo sac.defn: In angiosperms, the female gametophyte. Found within the ovule, it consists of eight or fewer cells, membrane bounded, but without cellulose walls between them.

embryonic stem cell.defn: A pluripotent cell in the blastocyst.

emigration.defn: Dispersal of individuals out of an existing population.

enamel.defn: The hard material, composed primarily of calcium phosphate, that covers the tooth.

endemic.defn: A species that occurs in a particular location and nowhere else on Earth.

endergonic.defn: A chemical reaction in which the products have higher free energy than the reactants, thereby requiring free energy input to occur.

endocrine gland.defn: An aggregation of secretory cells that secretes hormones into the blood. The endocrine system consists of all endocrine cells and endocrine glands in the body that produce and release hormones.

endocrines.defn: Chemical signals released by cells that enter the blood and affect cells anywhere in the body that have appropriate receptors. Also known as hormones.

endocytosis.defn: A process by which liquids or solid particles are taken up by a cell through invagination of the plasma membrane.

endoderm.defn: The innermost of the three embryonic germ layers delineated during gastrulation. Gives rise to the digestive and respiratory tracts and structures associated with them.

endodermis.defn: In plants, a specialized cell layer marking the inside of the cortex in roots and some stems. Frequently a barrier to free diffusion of solutes.

endogenous retroviruses.defn: Retroviruses that have been incorporated into the host's genome.

endomembrane system.defn: A system of intracellular membranes that exchange material with one another, consisting of the Golgi apparatus, endoplasmic reticulum, and lysosomes when present.

endometrium.defn: The epithelial lining of the uterus.

endoparasite.defn: A parasite that lives inside the body of its host organism.

endophytic fungi.defn: Fungi that live within the aboveground portions of plants without causing obvious harm to the host plant.

endoplasmic reticulum.defn: A system of membranous tubes and flattened sacs found in the cytoplasm of eukaryotes. Exists in two forms: rough ER, studded with ribosomes; and smooth ER, lacking ribosomes.

endorphins.defn: Molecules in the mammalian brain that act as neurotransmitters in pathways that control pain.

endoskeleton.defn: An internal skeleton covered by other, soft body tissues.

endosperm.defn: A specialized triploid seed tissue found only in angiosperms; contains stored nutrients for the developing embryo.

endospore.defn: In some bacteria, a resting structure that can survive harsh environmental conditions.

endosymbiosis theory.defn: The theory that the eukaryotic cell evolved via the engulfing of one prokaryotic cell by another.

endotherm.defn: An animal that can control its body temperature by the expenditure of its own metabolic energy.

endotoxin.defn: A lipopolysaccharide that forms part of the outer membrane of certain Gram-negative bacteria that is released when the bacteria grow or lyse.

energetic cost.defn: The difference between the energy an animal expends in performing a behavior and the energy it would have expended had it rested.

energy budget.defn: A quantitative description of all paths of energy exchange between an animal and its environment.

energy.defn: The capacity to do work or move matter against an opposing force. The capacity to accomplish change in physical and chemical systems.

enhancers.defn: Regulatory DNA sequences that bind transcription factors that either activate or increase the rate of transcription.

enkephalins.defn: Molecules in the mammalian brain that act as neurotransmitters in pathways that control pain.

enteric nervous system.defn: The nerve nets in the submucosa and between the smooth muscle layers of the vertebrate gut.

enthalpy.defn: The total energy of a system.

entrain.defn: To advance or delay an organism's circadian clock each day so that it is in phase with the light-dark cycle of the organism's environment.

entropy.defn: A measure of the degree of disorder in any system. Spontaneous reactions in a closed system are always accompanied by an increase in entropy.

enveloped virus.defn: A virus enclosed within a phospholipid membrane derived from its host cell.

environmental genomics.defn: Sequencing technique used when biologists are unable to work with the whole genome of a prokaryote species but instead examine individual genes collected from a random sample of the organism's environment.

environmentalism.defn: The use of ecological knowledge, along with economics, ethics, and many other considerations, to inform both personal decisions and public policy relating to stewardship of natural resources and ecosystems.

enzyme&#8211;substrate complex.defn: An intermediate in an enzyme-catalyzed reaction; consists of the enzyme bound to its substrate(s).

epiblast.defn: The upper or overlying portion of the avian blastula which is joined to the hypoblast at the margins of the blastodisc.

epiboly.defn: The movement of cells over the surface of the blastula toward the forming blastopore.

epidermis.defn: In plants and animals, the outermost cell layers. (Only one cell layer thick in plants.)

epididymis.defn: Coiled tubules in the testes that store sperm and conduct sperm from the seminiferous tubules to the vas deferens.

epigenetics.defn: The scientific study of changes in the expression of a gene or set of genes that occur without change in the DNA sequence.

epiglottis.defn: The flap of tissue that covers the entrance of the larynx to prevent food and liquid from entering the trachea.

epinephrine.defn: "The ""fight or flight"" hormone produced by the medulla of the adrenal gland; it also functions as a neurotransmitter. Also known as adrenaline."

epiphyseal plates.defn: Plates of cartilage near the ends of long bones where bone growth occurs up to adolescence when growth ceases.

epistasis.defn: Interaction between genes in which the presence of a particular allele of one gene determines whether another gene will be expressed.

epithelial tissue.defn: A type of animal tissue made up of sheets of cells that lines or covers organs, makes up tubules, and covers the surface of the body; one of the four major tissue types in multicellular animals.

epoch.defn: A subdivision of a period in a geological time scale.

equilibrium.defn: Any state of balanced opposing forces and no net change.

erection.defn: The state of the penis in which it is stiffened by engorgement with blood.

error signal.defn: In regulatory systems, any difference between the set point of the system and its current condition.

erythropoietin.defn: A hormone produced by the kidney in response to lack of oxygen that stimulates the production of red blood cells.

esophagus.defn: That part of the gut between the pharynx and the stomach.

essential amino acids.defn: Amino acids that an animal cannot synthesize for itself and must obtain from its food.

essential element.defn: A mineral nutrient required for normal growth and reproduction in plants and animals.

essential fatty acids.defn: Fatty acids that an animal cannot synthesize for itself and must obtain from its food.

ester linkage.defn: A condensation (water-releasing) reaction in which the carboxyl group of a fatty acid reacts with the hydroxyl group of an alcohol. Lipids, including most membrane lipids, are formed in this way.

estivation.defn: A state of dormancy and hypometabolism that occurs during the summer; usually a means of surviving drought and/or intense heat.

estrogen.defn: Any of several steroid sex hormones; produced chiefly by the ovaries in mammals.

estrus.defn: The period of heat, or maximum sexual receptivity, in some female mammals. Ordinarily, estrus is also the time of release of eggs in the female.

estuary.defn: An aquatic habitat in which salt water and fresh water mix, as when a river meets the ocean. Includes such ecosystems as salt marshes, mangrove forests, mudflats, and seagrass beds.

ether linkage.defn: The linkage of two hydro-carbons by an oxygen atom (HC—O—CH). Ether linkages are characteristic of the membrane lipids of the Archaea.

ethology.defn: An approach to the study of animal behavior that focuses on studying many species in natural environments and addresses questions about the evolution of behavior.

ethylene.defn: One of the plant growth hormones, the gas H<sub>2</sub>C═CH<sub>2</sub>. Involved in fruit ripening and other growth and developmental responses.

etiolated.defn: Process in flowering plants grown in the absence of light; characterized by long weak stems, smaller leaves due to longer internodes, and a pale yellow color.

euchromatin.defn: Diffuse, uncondensed chromatin. Contains active genes that will be transcribed into mRNA.

eukaryotes.defn: Organisms whose cells contain their genetic material inside a nucleus. Includes all life other than the viruses, prokaryotic archaea, and bacteria.

eusocial.defn: Pertaining to a social group that includes nonreproductive individuals, as in honey bees.

eustachian tube.defn: A connection between the middle ear and the throat that allows air pressure to equilibrate between the middle ear and the outside world. Also called the pharyngotympanic tube.

eutrophication.defn: A process in aquatic ecosystems initiated by a pulse of nutrients that results in an increase of algal growth that may lead to decomposition and depleted oxygen conditions (hypoxia).

evaporation.defn: The transition of water from the liquid to the gaseous phase.

evapotranspiration.defn: The evaporative transfer of heat and water from the surfaces of plants into the atmosphere, which reduces air temperature and increases moisture.

evolution.defn: Any gradual change. Most often refers to organic or Darwinian evolution, which is the genetic and resulting phenotypic change in populations of organisms from generation to generation.

evolutionary developmental biology.defn: The study of the interplay between evolutionary and developmental processes, with a focus on the genetic changes that give rise to novel morphology. Key concepts of evo-devo include modularity, genetic toolkits, genetic switches, and heterochrony.

evolutionary radiation.defn: The proliferation of many species within a single evolutionary lineage.

evolutionary reversal.defn: The reappearance of an ancestral trait in a group that had previously acquired a derived trait.

evolutionary theory.defn: The understanding and application of the mechanisms of evolutionary change to biological problems.

ex vivo gene therapy.defn: Alteration of the human genome sequence in the cells removed from the body and then reimplanted into the body for medical benefit.

excision repair.defn: DNA repair mechanism that removes damaged DNA and replaces it with the appropriate nucleotide.

excretory systems.defn: In animals, organs that maintain the volume, solute concentration, and composition of the extracellular fluid by excreting water, solutes, and nitrogenous wastes in the form of urine.

executive functions.defn: Cognitive processes (e.g., attentional control, inhibitory control, reasoning, problem solving, planning) that allow goal-directed control of thought and behavior.

exergonic.defn: A chemical reaction in which the products of the reaction have lower free energy than the reactants, resulting in a release of free energy.

exocrine gland.defn: Any gland, such as a salivary gland, that secretes to the outside of the body or into the gut.

exocytosis.defn: A process by which a vesicle within a cell fuses with the plasma membrane and releases its contents to the outside.

exon.defn: A portion of a DNA molecule, in eukaryotes, that codes for part of a polypeptide.

exoskeleton.defn: A hard covering on the outside of the body to which muscles are attached.

exotoxin.defn: A highly toxic, usually soluble protein released by living, multiplying bacteria.

expanding triplet repeat.defn: A three-base-pair sequence in a human gene that is unstable and can be repeated a few to hundreds of times. Often, the more the repeats, the less the activity of the gene involved. Expanding triplet repeats occur in some human diseases such as Huntington's disease and fragile-X syndrome.

expiratory reserve volume.defn: The amount of air that can be forcefully exhaled beyond the normal tidal expiration.

exploitation competition.defn: Competition in which both species reduce the quantities of their shared but limited resources.

exponential growth.defn: A pattern of population growth characterized by a multiplicative pattern in which, as the number of individuals increases, the number of new individuals added per unit time accelerates.

expression vector.defn: A DNA vector, such as a plasmid, that carries a DNA sequence for the expression of an inserted gene into mRNA and protein in a host cell.

expressivity.defn: The degree to which a genotype is expressed in the phenotype; may be affected by the environment.

extensor.defn: A muscle that extends an appendage.

external fertilization.defn: The release of gametes into the environment; typical of aquatic animals. Also called spawning.

external gills.defn: Highly branched and folded extensions of the body surface that provide a large surface area for gas exchange with water; typical of larval amphibians and many larval insects.

extracellular fluid.defn: In closed circulatory systems refers to the fluid in the circulatory system and the fluid outside it.

extracellular matrix.defn: A material of heterogeneous composition surrounding cells and performing many functions including adhesion of cells.

extraembryonic membranes.defn: Four membranes that support but are not part of the developing embryos of reptiles, birds, and mammals, defining these groups phylogenetically as amniotes.

extreme halophiles.defn: A group of euryarchaeotes that live exclusively in very salty environments.

extremophiles.defn: Archaea and bacteria that live and thrive under conditions (e.g., extremely high temperatures) that would kill most organisms.

eye cups.defn: Photosensory organs in flatworms; components of one of the simplest visual systems in animals.

F<sub>1</sub>.defn: The first filial generation; the immediate progeny of a parental (P) mating.

F<sub>2</sub>.defn: The second filial generation; the immediate progeny of a mating between members of the F<sub>1</sub> generation.

facilitated diffusion.defn: Passive movement through a membrane involving a specific carrier protein; does not proceed against a concentration gradient.

facultative.defn: A type of species interaction that is optional to at least one species involved in the interaction.

facultative anaerobe.defn: A prokaryote that can shift its metabolism between anaerobic and aerobic modes depending on the presence or absence of O<sub>2</sub>. Alternatively, facultative aerobe.

facultative parasite.defn: An organism that can parasitize other living organisms but is also capable of growing independently.

fast-twitch fibers.defn: "Skeletal muscle fibers that can generate high tension rapidly, but fatigue rapidly (""sprinter"" fibers). Characterized by an abundance of enzymes of glycolysis."

fat.defn: (1) A triglyceride that is solid at room temperature. (2) Adipose tissue, one type of connective tissue.

fate map.defn: "A diagram of the blastula showing which cells (blastomeres) are ""fated"" to contribute to specific tissues and organs in the mature body."

fatty acid.defn: A molecule made up of a long nonpolar hydrocarbon chain and a polar carboxyl group. Found in many lipids.

fauna.defn: All the animals found in a given area.

FLOWERING LOCUS D.defn: Gene coding for a transcription factor in the shoot apical meristem that binds to florigen; involved in the induction of flowering.

feather.defn: A structure growing from the skin of theropods (living birds and their extinct relatives) that consists of a hollow shaft fringed with vanes of barbs. Functions to support flight, plumage display, and thermoregulation.

feces.defn: Waste excreted from the digestive system.

fecundity.defn: The average number of offspring produced by each individual (or female) within the population.

feedback.defn: In regulatory systems, information about the relationship between the set point of the system and its current state.

feedforward information.defn: In regulatory systems, information that changes the set point of the system.

fenestrations.defn: Small holes in the walls of some capillaries.

fermentation.defn: The anaerobic degradation of a substance such as glucose to smaller molecules such as lactic acid or alcohol with the extraction of energy.

fertilization.defn: Union of gametes. Also known as syngamy.

fertilizer.defn: Any of a number of substances added to soil to improve the soil's capacity to support plant growth. May be organic or inorganic.

fiber.defn: In angiosperms, an elongated, tapering sclerenchyma cell, usually with a thick cell wall, that serves a support function in xylem.

fibrin.defn: A protein that polymerizes to form long threads that provide structure to a blood clot.

fibrinogen.defn: A circulating protein that can be stimulated to fall out of solution and provide the structure for a blood clot.

fibrous root system.defn: A root system typical of monocots composed of numerous thin adventitious roots that are all roughly equal in diameter.

Fick's law of diffusion.defn: An equation that describes the factors that determine the rate of diffusion of a molecule from an area of higher concentration to an area of lower concentration.

fight-or-flight response.defn: A rapid physiological response to a sudden threat mediated by the hormone epinephrine.

filament.defn: In flowers, the part of a stamen that supports the anther.

filter feeder.defn: An organism that feeds on organisms much smaller than itself that are suspended in water or air by means of a straining device. Also called suspension feeder.

first law of thermodynamics.defn: The principle that energy can be neither created nor destroyed.

first polar body.defn: The small daughter cell from the first meiotic division of a primary oocyte.

fitness.defn: The contribution of a genotype or phenotype to the genetic composition of subsequent generations, relative to the contribution of other genotypes or phenotypes.

fixed action pattern.defn: In ethology, a genetically determined behavior that is performed without learning, stereotypic (performed the same way each time), and not modifiable by learning.

fixed.defn: In population genetics, the change in a gene pool where there are at least two alleles of a gene to a situation where only one allele remains.

flagellum.defn: Long, whiplike appendage that propels cells. Prokaryotic flagella differ sharply from those found in eukaryotes.

flexor.defn: A muscle that flexes an appendage.

flora.defn: All of the plants found in a given area.

floral meristem.defn: In angiosperms, a meristem that forms the floral organs (sepals, petals, stamens, and carpels).

floral organ identity genes.defn: In angiosperms, genes that determine the fates of floral meristem cells; their expression is triggered by the products of meristem identity genes.

florigen.defn: A plant hormone involved in the conversion of a vegetative shoot apex to a flower.

flower.defn: The sexual structure of an angiosperm.

fluid feeder.defn: An animal that feeds on fluids it extracts from the bodies of other organisms; examples include nectar-feeding birds and blood-sucking insects.

fluid mosaic model.defn: A molecular model for the structure of biological membranes consisting of a fluid phospholipid bilayer in which suspended proteins are free to move in the plane of the bilayer.

follicle.defn: In female mammals, an immature egg surrounded by nutritive cells.

follicle-stimulating hormone.defn: A gonadotropin produced by the anterior pituitary.

food web.defn: A representation of the trophic or energetic connections among species within a community.

forebrain.defn: The region of the vertebrate brain that comprises the cerebrum, thalamus, and hypothalamus.

fossil fuels.defn: Fuels, including oil, natural gas, coal, and peat, formed over geologic time from organic material buried in anaerobic sediments.

foundation species.defn: A species that has large, community-wide effects as a consequence of its large size and abundance, and its provision of habitat or food for other species.

founder effect.defn: Random changes in allele frequencies resulting from establishment of a population by a very small number of individuals.

fovea.defn: In the vertebrate retina, the area of most distinct vision.

frame-shift mutation.defn: The addition or deletion of a single or two adjacent nucleotides in a gene's sequence. Results in the misreading of mRNA during translation and the production of a nonfunctional protein.

Frank&#8211;Starling law.defn: The principle that the stroke volume of the heart increases with increased return of blood to the heart.

free energy.defn: Energy that is available for doing useful work, after allowance has been made for the increase or decrease of disorder.

free-running.defn: A descriptor of an endogenous rhythm that is not entrained by an environmental cue.

frequency distribution.defn: A figure that displays the frequency of different classes of data.

frequency-dependent selection.defn: Selection that changes in intensity with the proportion of individuals in a population having the trait.

frontal lobe.defn: The largest of the brain lobes in humans; involved with feeling and planning functions; includes the primary motor cortex.

fruit.defn: In angiosperms, a ripened and mature ovary (or group of ovaries) containing the seeds. Sometimes applied to reproductive structures of other groups of plants.

FLOWERING LOCUS T.defn: Gene that codes for florigen, a small, diffusible protein involved in the induction of flowering.

fugitive species.defn: A species that leave an otherwise suitable habitat in order to avoid competition with another species.

full census.defn: A count of every individual in a population.

functional genomics.defn: The assignment of functional roles to the proteins encoded by genes identified by sequencing entire genomes.

functional group.defn: (1) A characteristic combination of atoms that contributes specific properties (such as charge or polarity) when attached to larger molecules (e.g., carboxyl group, amino group). (2) A group of species that function in similar ways, whether or not they use the same resources.

functional residual volume.defn: The residual volume plus the expiratory reserve volume.

fundamental niche.defn: A species' niche as defined by its physiological capabilities.

G protein.defn: A membrane protein involved in signal transduction; characterized by binding GDP or GTP.

G protein&#8211;coupled receptors.defn: A class of receptors that change configuration upon ligand binding such that a G protein binding site is exposed on the cytoplasmic domain of the receptor, initiating a signal transduction pathway.

G0.defn: A resting phase in which a cell is not preparing for the cell division cycle.

G1.defn: In the cell cycle, the gap between the end of mitosis and the onset of the S phase.

G1-to-S transition.defn: In the cell cycle, the point at which G1 ends and the S phase begins.

G2.defn: In the cell cycle, the gap between the S (synthesis) phase and the onset of mitosis.

gain-of-function mutation.defn: A mutation that results in a protein with a new function.

gallbladder.defn: In the human digestive system, an organ in which bile is stored.

gametangium.defn: Any plant or fungal structure within which a gamete is formed.

gamete.defn: The mature sexual reproductive cell: the egg or the sperm.

gametogenesis.defn: The specialized series of cellular divisions that leads to the production of gametes. Called oogenesis when referring to processes in the ovary and spermatogenesis in the testis.

gametophyte.defn: In plants and photosynthetic protists with alternation of generations, the multicellular haploid phase that produces the gametes.

gamma diversity.defn: Species diversity within a geographic region; the regional species pool.

ganglion.defn: A cluster of neurons that have similar characteristics or function.

ganglion cells.defn: Cells at the front of the human retina that transmit information from the bipolar cells to the brain.

gap genes.defn: In Drosophila development, segmentation genes that define broad areas along the anterior–posterior axis of the early embryo. Part of a developmental cascade that includes maternal effect genes, pair rule genes, segment polarity genes, and Hox genes.

gap junction.defn: A 2.7-nanometer gap between cell membranes of two animal cells, spanned by protein channels. Gap junctions allow chemical substances or electrical signals to pass from cell to cell.

gastric pits.defn: Deep infoldings in the walls of the stomach lined with secretory cells.

gastrin.defn: A hormone secreted by cells in the lower region of the stomach that stimulates the secretion of digestive juices as well as movements of the stomach.

gastrovascular cavity.defn: Serving for both digestion (gastro) and circulation (vascular); in particular, the central cavity of the body of jellyfish and other cnidarians.

gastrovascular system.defn: A branching body cavity in Cnidaria and Platyhelminthes that has one opening to the environment and serves to digest food and distribute nutrients to the body.

gastrulation.defn: Development of a blastula into a gastrula. In embryonic development, the process by which a blastula is transformed by massive movements of cells into a gastrula, an embryo with three germ layers and distinct body axes.

gated channel.defn: A membrane protein that changes its three-dimensional shape, and therefore its ion conductance, in response to a stimulus. When open, it allows specific ions to move across the membrane.

gel electrophoresis.defn: A technique for separating molecules (such as DNA fragments) from one another on the basis of their electric charges and molecular weights by applying an electric field to a gel.

gene.defn: A unit of heredity. Used here as the unit of genetic function which carries the information for a polypeptide or RNA.

gene duplication.defn: The generation of extra copies of a gene in a genome over evolutionary time. A mechanism by which genomes can acquire new functions.

gene expression.defn: The transcription and translation into a protein of the information (nucleotide sequence) contained in a gene.

gene family.defn: A set of similar genes derived from a single parent gene; need not be on the same chromosomes. The vertebrate globin genes constitute a classic example of a gene family.

gene pool.defn: All of the different alleles of all of the genes existing in all individuals of a population.

gene therapy.defn: Treatment of a genetic disease by providing patients with cells containing functioning alleles of the genes that are nonfunctional in their bodies.

gene tree.defn: A graphic representation of the evolutionary relationships of a single gene in different species or of the members of a gene family.

gene-for-gene concept.defn: In plants, a mechanism of resistance to pathogens in which resistance is triggered by the specific interaction of the products of a pathogen's Avr genes and a plant's R genes.

general transcription factors.defn: In eukaryotes, transcription factors that bind to the promoters of most protein-coding genes and are required for their expression. Distinct from transcription factors that have specific regulatory effects only at certain promoters or classes of promoters.

generation time.defn: The average age of the parents of all the offspring produced within a cohort.

genetic code.defn: The set of instructions, in the form of nucleotide triplets, that translate a linear sequence of nucleotides in mRNA into a linear sequence of amino acids in a protein.

genetic drift.defn: Changes in gene frequencies from generation to generation as a result of random (chance) processes.

genetic marker.defn: (1) In gene cloning, a gene of identifiable phenotype that indicates the presence of another gene, DNA segment, or chromosome fragment. (2) In general, a DNA sequence such as a single nucleotide polymorphism whose presence is correlated with the presence of other linked genes on that chromosome.

genetic screen.defn: A technique for identifying genes involved in a biological process of interest. Involves creating a large collection of randomly mutated organisms and identifying those individuals that are likely to have a defect in the pathway of interest. The mutated gene(s) in those individuals can then be isolated for further study.

genetic structure.defn: The frequencies of different alleles at each locus and the frequencies of different genotypes in a Mendelian population.

genetic switches.defn: Mechanisms that control how the genetic toolkit is used, such as promoters and the transcription factors that bind them. The signal cascades that converge on and operate these switches determine when and where genes will be turned on and off.

genetic toolkit.defn: A set of developmental genes and proteins that is common to most animals and is hypothesized to be responsible for the evolution of their differing developmental pathways.

genetics.defn: The scientific study of the structure, functioning, and inheritance of genes, the units of hereditary information.

genitalia.defn: The reproductive organs, especially the external accessory sex organs.

genome.defn: The complete DNA sequence for a particular organism or individual.

genome sequencing.defn: Determination of the nucleotide base sequence of the entire genome of an organism.

genomic equivalence.defn: All somatic cells in a complex organism have the entire genome of that organism.

genomic library.defn: All of the cloned DNA fragments generated by the breakdown of genomic DNA into smaller segments.

genomics.defn: The scientific study of entire sets of genes and their interactions.

genotype.defn: An exact description of the genetic constitution of an individual, either with respect to a single trait or with respect to a larger set of traits.

genus.defn: A group of related, similar species recognized by taxonomists with a distinct name used in binomial nomenclature.

geographic range.defn: The entire region within which a species occurs.

geological time scale.defn: The division of Earth's history into ordered, named periods of time, based on major biotic and abiotic changes.

germ cell.defn: A reproductive cell or gamete of a multicellular organism.

germ layers.defn: The three embryonic layers formed during gastrulation (ectoderm, mesoderm, and endoderm). Also called cell layers or tissue layers.

germ line gene therapy.defn: Alteration of the human genome sequence in the gametes or cells giving rise to gametes for medical benefit.

germ line mutation.defn: Mutation in a cell that produces gametes (i.e., a germ line cell).

germination.defn: Sprouting of a seed or spore.

gestation.defn: The period during which the embryo of a mammal develops within the uterus. Also known as pregnancy.

ghrelin.defn: A hormone produced and secreted by cells in the stomach that stimulates appetite.

gibberellin.defn: A class of plant growth hormones playing roles in stem elongation, seed germination, flowering of certain plants, etc.

gizzard.defn: The second of two stomachlike organs in birds, other reptiles, earthworms, and various insects, that grinds up food, sometimes with the aid of fragments of stone.

glans penis.defn: The highly sensitive tip of the mammalian penis.

glia.defn: One of the two classes of neural cells (along with neurons, with which glia interact); glia do not typically conduct action potentials. Types of glia include astrocytes, oligodendrocytes, and Schwann cells.

glomerular filtration rate.defn: The rate at which the blood is filtered in the glomeruli of the kidney.

glomerulus.defn: Sites in the kidney where blood filtration takes place. Each glomerulus consists of a knot of capillaries served by afferent and efferent arterioles.

glucagon.defn: Hormone produced by alpha cells of the pancreatic islets of Langerhans. Glucagon stimulates the liver to break down glycogen and release glucose into the circulation.

gluconeogenesis.defn: The biochemical synthesis of glucose from other substances, such as amino acids, lactate, and glycerol.

glucose.defn: The most common monosaccharide; the monomer of the polysaccharides starch, glycogen, and cellulose.

glyceraldehyde 3-phosphate.defn: A phosphorylated three-carbon sugar; an intermediate in glycolysis and photosynthetic carbon fixation.

glycerol.defn: A three-carbon alcohol with three hydroxyl groups; a component of phospholipids and triglycerides.

glycogen.defn: An energy storage polysaccharide found in animals and fungi; a branched-chain polymer of glucose, similar to starch.

glycolipid.defn: A lipid to which sugars are attached.

glycolysis.defn: The enzymatic breakdown of glucose to pyruvic acid.

glycoprotein.defn: A protein to which sugars are attached.

glycosidic linkage.defn: Bond between carbohydrate (sugar) molecules through an intervening oxygen atom (–O–).

glycosylation.defn: The addition of carbohydrates to another type of molecule, such as a protein.

glyoxysome.defn: An organelle found in plants, in which stored lipids are converted to carbohydrates.

goiter.defn: Swelling in the neck resulting from an enlarged thyroid gland.

Goldman equation.defn: An equation that calculates membrane potential by taking into consideration the concentration differences of all ions on both sides of the membrane and the relative permeability of the membrane to those ions.

Golgi apparatus.defn: A system of concentrically folded membranes found in the cytoplasm of eukaryotic cells; functions in secretion from the cell by exocytosis.

Golgi tendon organ.defn: A mechanoreceptor found in tendons and ligaments; provides information about the force generated by a contracting muscle.

gonad.defn: An organ that produces gametes in animals: either an ovary (female gonad) or testis (male gonad).

gonadotropin.defn: A trophic hormone that stimulates the gonads.

gonadotropin-releasing hormone.defn: Hormone produced by the hypothalamus that stimulates the anterior pituitary to secrete gonadotropins.

Gondwana.defn: The large southern land mass that existed from the Cambrian (540 mya) to the Jurassic (138 mya). Present-day remnants are South America, Africa, India, Australia, and Antarctica.

graded membrane potential.defn: Small local change in membrane potential caused by opening or closing of ion channels.

grafting.defn: Artificial transplantation of tissue from one organism to another. In horticulture, the transfer of a bud or stem segment from one plant onto the root of another as a form of asexual reproduction.

Gram-negative bacteria.defn: Bacteria that appear red when stained using the Gram-staining technique. These bacteria have an outer membrane outside the relatively thin peptidoglycan layer of the cell wall.

Gram-positive bacteria.defn: Bacteria that appear blue to purple when stained using the Gram-staining technique. These bacteria have an outer cell wall consisting of a thick layer of peptidoglycan.

Gram stain.defn: A differential purple stain useful in characterizing bacteria. The peptidoglycan-rich cell walls of gram-positive bacteria stain purple; cell walls of gram-negative bacteria generally stain orange.

granulosa cells.defn: Cells of the ovarian follicle of mammals that surround and nurture the oocyte.

gravitropism.defn: A directed plant growth response to gravity.

gray crescent.defn: In frog development, a band of diffusely pigmented cytoplasm on the side of the egg opposite the site of sperm entry. Arises as a result of cytoplasmic rearrangements that establish the anterior–posterior axis of the zygote.

gray matter.defn: In the nervous system, tissue that is rich in neuronal cell bodies.

greenhouse gases.defn: Gases in the atmosphere, such as carbon dioxide and methane, that are transparent to sunlight, but trap heat radiating from Earth's surface, causing heat to build up at Earth's surface.

gross primary production.defn: The total amount of carbon fixed by primary producers in an ecosystem.

ground meristem.defn: That part of an apical meristem that gives rise to the ground tissue system of the primary plant body.

ground tissue system.defn: Those parts of the plant body not included in the dermal or vascular tissue systems. Ground tissues function in storage, photosynthesis, and support.

growth.defn: An increase in the size of the body and its organs by cell division and cell expansion.

growth factor.defn: A chemical signal that stimulates cells to divide.

growth hormone.defn: A peptide hormone released by the anterior pituitary that stimulates many anabolic processes.

growth hormone inhibiting hormone.defn: Also called somatostatin, a peptide hormone produced in the hypothalamus that inhibits the activity of growth hormone secreting cells in the anterior pituitary.

guanine.defn: A nitrogen-containing base found in DNA, RNA, and GTP.

guard cells.defn: In plants, specialized, paired epidermal cells that surround and control the opening of a stoma (pore).

guild.defn: A group of species, often taxonomically distinct, that use the same resources.

gymnosperms.defn: Seed plants that do not produce flowers or fruits; one of the two major groups of living seed plants.

gyres.defn: Large-scale circular ocean currents caused by prevailing winds and Earth's rotation.

gyri.defn: The ridges (folds) in the cerebral cortex.

habitat.defn: The particular environment in which an organism lives.

habitat degradation.defn: The conversion of an ecosystem by human activities that reduces habitat quality.

habitat loss.defn: The conversion of an ecosystem by human activities that reduces habitat quantity.

hair cell.defn: A type of mechanoreceptor in animals. Detects sound waves and other forms of motion in air or water.

half-life.defn: The time required for half of a sample of a radioactive isotope to decay to its stable, nonradioactive form, or for a drug or other substance to reach half its initial dosage.

halophytes.defn: Organisms that can grow in high salinity.

Hamilton's rule.defn: The principle that, for an apparent altruistic behavior to be adaptive, the fitness benefit of that act to the recipient times the degree of relatedness of the performer and the recipient must be greater than the cost to the performer.

haplodiploidy.defn: A sex determination mechanism in which diploid individuals (which develop from fertilized eggs) are female and haploid individuals (which develop from unfertilized eggs) are male; typical of hymenopterans.

haploid.defn: Having a chromosome complement consisting of just one copy of each chromosome; designated 1n or n.

haplotype.defn: "Linked nucleotide sequences that are usually inherited as a unit (as a ""sentence"" rather than as individual ""words"")."

Hardy&#8211;Weinberg equilibrium.defn: In a sexually reproducing population, the allele frequency at a given locus that is not being acted on by agents of evolution; the conditions that would result in no evolution in a population.

haustorium.defn: A specialized hypha or other structure by which fungi and some parasitic plants draw nutrients from a host plant.

Haversian systems.defn: Units of organization in compact bone that reflect the action of intercommunicating osteoblasts.

heart.defn: In circulatory systems, a muscular pump that moves extracellular fluid around the body.

heat of vaporization.defn: The energy that must be supplied to convert a molecule from a liquid to a gas at its boiling point.

heat shock proteins.defn: Chaperone proteins expressed in cells exposed to high or low temperatures or other forms of environmental stress.

hematocrit.defn: The proportion of the blood volume that consists of red blood cells.

hemiparasite.defn: A parasitic plant that can photosynthesize, but derives water and mineral nutrients from the living body of another plant.

hemizygous.defn: In a diploid organism, having only one allele for a given trait, typically the case for X-linked genes in male mammals and Z-linked genes in female birds.

hemocoel.defn: The primary body cavity of many invertebrates, which contains circulatory fluid.

hemoglobin.defn: Oxygen-transporting protein found in the red blood cells of vertebrates (and found in some invertebrates).

hemolymph.defn: The extracellular fluid in closed circulatory systems.

Hensen's node.defn: In avian embryos, a structure at the anterior end of the primitive groove; determines the fates of cells passing over it during gastrulation.

hepatic portal vein.defn: The vein that begins in capillary beds in the gut and ends in capillary beds in the liver.

herbivore.defn: An animal that eats plant tissues.

herbivory.defn: An act of predation in which the predator is animal and the prey is a plant or algae.

hermaphroditism.defn: The coexistence of both female and male sex organs in the same organism.

heterochromatin.defn: Densely packed, dark-staining chromatin; any genes it contains are usually not transcribed.

heterochrony.defn: Alteration in the timing of developmental events, contributing to the evolution of different phenotypes in the adult.

heterocyst.defn: A large, thick-walled cell type in the filaments of certain cyanobacteria that performs nitrogen fixation.

heterometry.defn: Alteration in the level of gene expression, and thus in the amount of protein produced, during development, contributing to the evolution of different phenotypes in the adult.

heteromorphic.defn: Having a different form or appearance, as two heteromorphic life stages of a plant.

heterosis.defn: The superior fitness of heterozygous offspring as compared with that of their dissimilar homozygous parents. Also called hybrid vigor.

heterosporous.defn: Producing two types of spores, one of which gives rise to a female megaspore and the other to a male microspore.

heterotherm.defn: An animal that regulates its body temperature at a constant level at some times but not others, such as a hibernator.

heterotopy.defn: Spatial differences in gene expression during development, controlled by developmental regulatory genes and contributing to the evolution of distinctive adult phenotypes.

heterotroph.defn: An organism that requires preformed organic molecules as food.

heterotypy.defn: Alteration in a developmental regulatory gene itself rather than the expression of the genes it controls.

heterozygous.defn: In diploid organisms, having different alleles of a given gene on the pair of homologs carrying that gene.

hexose.defn: A sugar containing six carbon atoms.

hibernation.defn: The state of inactivity of some animals during winter; marked by a drop in body temperature and metabolic rate.

high-density lipoproteins.defn: "Lipoproteins that remove cholesterol from tissues and carry it to the liver; HDLs are the ""good"" lipoproteins associated with good cardiovascular health."

high-throughput sequencing.defn: Rapid DNA sequencing on a micro scale in which many fragments of DNA are sequenced in parallel.

highly repetitive sequences.defn: Short (less than 100 bp), nontranscribed DNA sequences, repeated thousands of times in tandem arrangements.

hindbrain.defn: The region of the developing vertebrate brain that gives rise to the medulla, pons, and cerebellum.

hippocampus.defn: A part of the forebrain that takes part in long-term memory formation.

histamine.defn: A substance released by damaged tissue, or by mast cells in response to allergens. Histamine increases vascular permeability, leading to edema (swelling).

histogram.defn: A figure that displays frequencies of classes of quantitative data binned by ranges of a particular variable.

holoparasite.defn: A fully parasitic plant (i.e., one that does not perform photosynthesis).

homeobox.defn: 180-base-pair segment of DNA found in certain homeotic genes. A specific sequence within the homeobox—the homeodomain—regulates the expression of other genes and through this regulation controls large-scale developmental processes.

homeostasis.defn: The maintenance of a steady state, such as a constant temperature, by means of physiological or behavioral feedback responses.

homeotherms.defn: Animals that regulate their body temperatures within a narrow range when confronted with a much greater range of environmental temperatures.

homeotic genes.defn: Genes that act during development to determine the formation of an organ from a region of the embryo.

homeotic mutation.defn: Mutation in a homeotic gene that results in the formation of a different organ than that normally made by a region of the embryo.

homing.defn: In animal navigation, the ability to return to a nest site, burrow, or other specific location.

hominin.defn: Lineages that includes modern humans (Homo sapiens) and their extinct ancestors (e.g., Australopithecines, Homo erectus).

homolog.defn: (1) In cytogenetics, one of a pair (or larger set) of chromosomes having the same overall genetic composition and sequence. In diploid organisms, each chromosome inherited from one parent is matched by an identical (except for mutational changes) chromosome—its homolog—from the other parent. (2) In evolutionary biology, one of two or more features in different species that are similar by reason of descent from a common ancestor.

homologous pair.defn: A pair of matching chromosomes made up of a chromosome from each of the two sets of chromosomes in a diploid organism.

homology.defn: A similarity between two or more features that is due to inheritance from a common ancestor. The structures are said to be homologous, and each is a homolog of the others.

homoplasy.defn: The presence in multiple groups of a trait that is not inherited from the common ancestor of those groups. Can result from convergent evolution, evolutionary reversal, or parallel evolution.

homosporous.defn: Producing a single type of spore that gives rise to a single type of gametophyte, bearing both female and male reproductive organs.

homotypic.defn: Pertaining to adhesion of cells of the same type.

homozygous.defn: In diploid organisms, having identical alleles of a given gene on both homologous chromosomes. An individual may be a homozygote with respect to one gene and a heterozygote with respect to another.

horizons.defn: The horizontal layers of a soil profile, including the topsoil (A horizon), subsoil (B horizon) and parent rock or bedrock (C horizon).

horizontal cells.defn: Cells in the retina that communicate laterally between photoreceptors and bipolar cells.

hormone.defn: A chemical signal produced in minute amounts at one site in a multicellular organism and transported to another site where it acts on target cells.

host.defn: An organism that harbors a parasite or symbiont and provides it with nourishment.

Hox genes.defn: Conserved homeotic genes found in vertebrates, Drosophila, and other animal groups. Hox genes contain the homeobox and specify pattern and axis formation in these animals.

human chorionic gonadotropin.defn: A hormone secreted by the placenta that sustains the corpus luteum and helps maintain pregnancy.

Human Genome Project.defn: A publicly and privately funded research effort, successfully completed in 2003, to produce a complete DNA sequence for the entire human genome.

human immunodeficiency virus.defn: Human immunodeficiency virus, the retrovirus that causes acquired immune deficiency syndrome (AIDS).

humoral immune response.defn: The response of the immune system mediated by B cells that produces circulating antibodies active against extracellular bacterial and viral infections.

humus.defn: The partly decomposed remains of plants and animals on the surface of a soil.

hybrid zone.defn: A region of overlap in the ranges of two closely related species where the species may hybridize.

hydrocarbon.defn: A compound containing only carbon and hydrogen atoms.

hydrogen bond.defn: A weak electrostatic bond which arises from the attraction between the slight positive charge on a hydrogen atom and a slight negative charge on a nearby oxygen or nitrogen atom.

hydrologic cycle.defn: The movement of water from the oceans to the atmosphere, to the soil, rivers, and lakes, and back to the oceans.

hydrolysis reaction.defn: A chemical reaction that breaks a bond by inserting the components of water (AB + H<sub>2</sub>O → AH + BOH).

hydrophobic.defn: Having no affinity for water. Uncharged and nonpolar groups of atoms are hydrophobic.

hydrophobic interaction.defn: A weak chemical interaction caused when molecules that are not attracted to water interact to exclude water.

hydroponic.defn: Pertaining to a method of growing plants with their roots suspended in nutrient solutions instead of soil.

hydrostatic skeleton.defn: A fluid-filled body cavity that transfers forces from one part of the body to another when acted on by surrounding muscles.

hyperaccumulators.defn: Plant species that store large quantities of heavy metals such as arsenic, cadmium, nickel, aluminum, and zinc.

hyperpolarization.defn: A change in the resting potential across a membrane so that the inside of a cell becomes more negative compared with the outside of the cell.

hypersensitive response.defn: A defensive response of plants to microbial infection in which phytoalexins and pathogenesis-related proteins are produced and the infected tissue undergoes apoptosis to isolate the pathogen from the rest of the plant.

hypertonic.defn: Having a greater solute concentration. Said of one solution compared with another.

hypertonic regulation.defn: Maintaining body fluids at a greater solute concentration than the environment.

hypha.defn: In the fungi and oomycetes, any single filament.

hypoblast.defn: The lower tissue portion of the avian blastula which is joined to the epiblast at the margins of the blastodisc.

hypothalamus.defn: The part of the brain lying below the thalamus; it coordinates water balance, reproduction, temperature regulation, and metabolism.

hypothesis.defn: A tentative answer to a question, from which testable predictions can be generated.

hypotonic.defn: Having a lesser solute concentration. Said of one solution in comparing it to another.

hypotonic regulation.defn: Maintaining body fluids at a lesser solute concentration than the environment.

hysteresis.defn: The inability of a community that has undergone change to shift back to the initial community type, even when the original conditions are restored.

igneous rocks.defn: Rocks solidified from lava or magma.

ileum.defn: The final segment of the small intestine.

imbibition.defn: Water uptake by a seed; first step in germination.

immediate hypersensitivity.defn: A rapid, extensive overreaction of the immune system against an allergen, resulting in the release of large amounts of histamine.

immediate memory.defn: A form of memory for events happening in the present that is almost perfectly photographic, but lasts only seconds.

immigration.defn: Dispersal of individuals into an existing population.

immunity.defn: In animals, the ability to avoid disease when invaded by a pathogen by deploying various defense mechanisms.

immunoglobulins.defn: A class of proteins containing a tetramer consisting of four polypeptide chains—two identical light chains and two identical heavy chains—held together by disulfide bonds; active as receptors and effectors in the immune system.

immunological memory.defn: The capacity to more rapidly and massively respond to a second exposure to an antigen than occurred on first exposure.

imperfect flower.defn: A flower lacking either functional stamens or functional carpels.

implantation.defn: The process by which the early mammalian embryo becomes attached to and embedded in the lining of the uterus.

imprinting.defn: In animal behavior, a rapid form of learning in which an animal learns, during a brief critical period, to make a particular response (which is then maintained for life) to some object or other organism.

in vitro evolution.defn: A method based on natural molecular evolution that uses artificial selection in the laboratory to rapidly produce molecules with novel enzymatic and binding functions.

in vivo gene therapy.defn: Alteration of the human genome sequence in cells in the body for medical benefit.

inactivation gate.defn: The property of a voltage-gated Na+ ion channel that decreases its permeability to Na+ when the membrane is depolarized.

inbreeding.defn: Breeding of two closely genetically related individuals.

inbreeding depression.defn: Reduction of fitness in the offspring of inbreeding.

inclusive fitness.defn: The sum of an individual's genetic contribution to subsequent generations both via production of its own offspring and via its influence on the survival of relatives who are not direct descendants.

incomplete cleavage.defn: A pattern of cleavage that occurs in many eggs that have a lot of yolk, in which the cleavage furrows do not penetrate all of it.

incomplete dominance.defn: Condition in which the heterozygous phenotype is intermediate between the two homozygous phenotypes.

incomplete metamorphosis.defn: Insect development in which changes between instars are gradual.

independent assortment.defn: During meiosis, the random separation of genes carried on nonhomologous chromosomes into gametes so that inheritance of these genes is random. This principle was articulated by Mendel as his second law.

indeterminate growth.defn: An open-ended growth pattern in which an organism or organ continues to grow as long as it lives; characteristic of some animals and of plant shoots and roots.

indirect fitness.defn: "The component of inclusive fitness due to the reproductive success of related individuals times the percentage of shared genes between those individuals (e.g., 50

indirect interaction.defn: An interaction in which the relationship between two species is mediated by a third (or more) species.

induced.defn: A process that occurs only under certain conditions or signals.

induced fit.defn: A change in the shape of an enzyme caused by binding to its substrate that exposes the active site of the enzyme.

induced mutation.defn: A mutation resulting from exposure to a mutagen from outside the cell.

induced pluripotent stem cells.defn: Multipotent or pluripotent animal stem cells produced from differentiated cells in vitro by the addition of several genes that are expressed.

inducer.defn: (1) A compound that stimulates the synthesis of a protein. (2) In embryonic development, a substance that causes a group of target cells to differentiate in a particular way.

inducible.defn: Produced only in the presence of a particular compound or under particular circumstances.

inducible genes.defn: Genes that are expressed only when their products—inducible proteins—are needed.

induction.defn: In embryonic development, the process by which a factor produced and secreted by certain cells determines the fates of other cells.

inductive logic.defn: Involves making observations and then formulating one or more possible scenarios—hypotheses—that might explain those observations.

inferior vena cava.defn: Large vein that returns deoxygenated blood to the right atrium from the lower body.

inflammation.defn: A nonspecific defense against pathogens; characterized by redness, swelling, pain, and increased temperature.

inflorescence.defn: A structure composed of several to many flowers.

inflorescence meristem.defn: A meristem that produces floral meristems as well as other small leafy structures (bracts).

ingroup.defn: In a phylogenetic study, the group of organisms of primary interest.

initials.defn: Cells that perpetuate plant meristems, comparable to animal stem cells. When an initial divides, one daughter cell develops into another initial, while the other differentiates into a more specialized cell.

initiation.defn: In molecular biology, the beginning of transcription or translation.

initiation complex.defn: In protein translation, a combination of a small ribosomal subunit, an mRNA molecule, and the tRNA charged with the first amino acid coded for by the mRNA; formed at the onset of translation.

initiation site.defn: The place within a promoter where transcription begins.

innate defenses.defn: In animals, one of two general types of defenses against pathogens. Nonspecific and present in most animals.

inner cell mass.defn: Derived from the mammalian blastula (blastocyst), the inner cell mass that will give rise to the yolk sac (via hypoblast) and embryo (via epiblast).

inorganic fertilizer.defn: A chemical or combination of chemicals applied to soil or plants to make up for a plant nutrient deficiency. Often contains the macronutrients nitrogen, phosphorus, and potassium (N-P-K).

inositol trisphosphate.defn: An intracellular second messenger derived from membrane phospholipids.

inspiratory reserve volume.defn: The amount of air that can be inhaled above the normal tidal inspiration.

instar.defn: An immature stage of an insect between molts.

insular cortex.defn: The outer layers of the insular lobe.

insular lobe.defn: A region of the cerebrum that folds in between the temporal lobes and the overlying frontal and parietal lobes.

insulin.defn: A hormone synthesized in islet cells of the pancreas that promotes the conversion of glucose into the storage material, glycogen.

integral membrane proteins.defn: Proteins that are at least partially embedded in the plasma membrane.

integrin.defn: In animals, a transmembrane protein that mediates the attachment of epithelial cells to the extracellular matrix.

integument.defn: A protective surface structure. In gymnosperms and angiosperms, a layer of tissue around the ovule that will become the seed coat.

interaction strength.defn: A measure of the effect of one species (the interactor) on the abundance of another species (the target species).

interaction webs.defn: A concept that describes both the trophic (vertical) and non-trophic (horizontal; such as competition, mutualism, commensalism) interactions among the species in a food web.

intercalated discs.defn: Structural features of cardiac muscle cells that connect cells together and provide electrical continuity through gap junctions.

intercostal muscles.defn: Muscles between the ribs that can augment breathing movements by elevating and suppressing the rib cage.

interference competition.defn: Competition in which one species actively interferes with another species' access to a limiting resource.

interferons.defn: Glycoproteins produced by virus-infected animal cells; interferons increase the resistance of neighboring cells to the virus.

intermediate disturbance hypothesis.defn: A hypothesis describing how varying degrees of disturbance (or stress or predation) affects species diversity within communities. Species diversity is greatest at intermediate levels of disturbance because competitive exclusion at low levels of disturbance and mortality at high levels of disturbance reduces species diversity.

intermediate filaments.defn: A part of the cytoskeleton that includes filaments intermediate in diameter between microtubules and microfilaments.

internal environment.defn: In multicellular organisms, includes blood plasma and interstitial fluid (i.e., the extracellular fluids that surround the cells).

internal fertilization.defn: The release of sperm into the female reproductive tract; typical of most terrestrial animals.

internal gills.defn: Gills enclosed in protective body cavities; typical of mollusks, arthropods, and fishes.

interneuron.defn: A neuron that communicates information between two other neurons.

internode.defn: The region between two nodes of a plant stem.

interphase.defn: In the cell cycle, the period between successive nuclear divisions during which the chromosomes are diffuse and the nuclear envelope is intact. During interphase the cell is most active in transcribing and translating genetic information.

interspecific interactions.defn: Interactions between members of two or more species.

interstitial fluid.defn: Extracellular fluid that is not contained in the vessels of a circulatory system.

intertidal zone.defn: A nearshore region of oceans that is periodically exposed to the air as the tides rise and fall.

intestine.defn: The portion of the gut following the stomach, in which most digestion and absorption occurs.

intracellular receptor.defn: A receptor that binds its ligand inside the cell. An example is the estrogen receptor in mammals.

intraspecific competition.defn: Competition for shared limited resources by individuals of the same species.

intron.defn: Portion of a gene within the coding region that is transcribed into pre-mRNA but is spliced out prior to translation.

invasive species.defn: A non-native species that reproduces rapidly, spreads widely, and has mostly negative effects on the native species or ecosystems of the region to which it has been introduced.

inversion.defn: A rare 180<sup>°</sup> reversal of the order of genes within a segment of a chromosome.

involution.defn: Cell movements that occur during gastrulation of frog embryos, giving rise to the archenteron.

ion.defn: An electrically charged particle that forms when an atom gains or loses one or more electrons.

ion channel.defn: An integral membrane protein that allows ions to diffuse across the membrane in which it is embedded.

ionic attraction.defn: An electrostatic attraction between positively and negatively charged ions.

iris.defn: The round, pigmented membrane that surrounds the pupil of the eye and adjusts its aperture to regulate the amount of light entering the eye.

islets of Langerhans.defn: Clusters of hormone-producing cells in the pancreas.

isomers.defn: Molecules consisting of the same numbers and kinds of atoms, but differing in the bonding patterns by which the atoms are held together.

isomorphic.defn: Having the same form or appearance, as when the haploid and diploid life stages of an organism appear identical.

isotonic.defn: Having the same solute concentration; said of two solutions.

isotope.defn: Isotopes of a given chemical element have the same number of protons in their nuclei (and thus are in the same position on the periodic table), but differ in the number of neutrons.

isozymes.defn: Enzymes of an organism that have somewhat different amino acid sequences but catalyze the same reaction.

iteroparity.defn: Reproducing multiple times in a lifetime.

jasmonic acid (jasmonate).defn: A plant hormone involved in triggering responses to pathogen attack as well as other processes.

jejunum.defn: The middle division of the small intestine, where most absorption of nutrients occurs.

joint.defn: In skeletal systems, a junction between two or more bones.

juvenile hormone.defn: In insects, a hormone maintaining larval growth and preventing maturation or pupation.

juxtacrine.defn: A mode of cell communication where the cell producing a signal is in contact with the cell bearing the receptor for that signal.

K-strategist.defn: A species whose life history strategy allows it to persist at or near the carrying capacity (K) of its environment.

karyogamy.defn: The fusion of nuclei of two cells.

karyotype.defn: The number, forms, and types of chromosomes in a cell.

keystone species.defn: Species that have strong community-wide effects despite their small size and abundance.

kidneys.defn: A pair of excretory organs in vertebrates.

kin selection.defn: That component of inclusive fitness resulting from helping the survival of relatives containing the same alleles by descent from a common ancestor.

kinetochore.defn: Specialized structure on a centromere to which microtubules attach.

Koch's postulates.defn: A set of rules for establishing that a particular microorganism causes a particular disease.

lacteals.defn: The smallest vessels of the lymphatic system.

lactic acid fermentation.defn: A metabolic pathway in which glucose is catabolized in the absence of oxygen with the production of lactic acid.

lagging strand.defn: In DNA replication, the daughter strand that is synthesized in discontinuous stretches.

landscape.defn: A geographic area consisting of multiple ecosystems or habitats.

larva.defn: An immature stage of any animal that differs dramatically in appearance from the adult.

larynx.defn: A structure between the pharynx and trachea that contains the vocal cords.

lateral gene transfer.defn: The transfer of genes from one species to another, common among bacteria and archaea.

lateral meristem.defn: Either of the two meristems, the vascular cambium and the cork cambium, that give rise to a plant's secondary growth.

lateral root.defn: A root extending outward from the taproot in a taproot system; typical of eudicots.

lateralization.defn: A phenomenon in humans in which language functions come to reside in one cerebral hemisphere, usually the left.

laticifers.defn: In some plants, elongated cells containing secondary plant products such as latex.

Laurasia.defn: The northernmost of the two large continents produced by the breakup of Pangaea.

law of mass action.defn: The rate of a chemical reaction is directly proportional to the concentrations of the reacting substances.

laws of thermodynamics.defn: Laws derived from studies of the physical properties of energy and the ways energy interacts with matter.

leaching.defn: In soils, a process by which mineral nutrients in upper soil horizons are dissolved in water and carried to deeper horizons, where they are unavailable to plant roots.

leading strand.defn: In DNA replication, the daughter strand that is synthesized continuously.

leaf.defn: In plants, the chief organ of photosynthesis.

leaf primordium.defn: An outgrowth on the side of the shoot apical meristem that will eventually develop into a leaf.

leghemoglobin.defn: In nitrogen-fixing plants, an oxygen-carrying protein in the cytoplasm of nodule cells that transports enough oxygen to the nitrogen-fixing bacteria to support their respiration, while keeping free oxygen concentrations low enough to protect nitrogenase.

lek.defn: A display ground within which male animals compete for and defend small display areas as a means of demonstrating their territorial prowess and winning opportunities to mate.

lens.defn: In the vertebrate eye, a crystalline protein structure that makes fine adjustments in the focus of images falling on the retina.

lenticels.defn: Small porous regions on the bark of woody stems and roots in dicots.

leptin.defn: A hormone produced by fat cells that is believed to provide feedback information to the brain about the status of the body's fat reserves.

Leydig cells.defn: The cells between the seminiferous tubules of the testes that secrete testosterone.

lichen.defn: An organism resulting from the symbiotic association of a fungus and either a cyanobacterium or a unicellular alga.

life history.defn: The lifetime pattern of growth, reproduction, and survival for an average individual.

life history strategy.defn: The way in which individuals within and among species allocate resources to growth, reproduction, and survival based on genetic and environmental factors.

life table.defn: A summary of how survival and reproductive rates vary with the age, size, or sex of individuals within a population, and used to estimate population growth rate.

ligament.defn: A band of connective tissue linking two bones in a joint.

ligand.defn: Any molecule that binds to a receptor site of another (usually larger) molecule.

light reactions.defn: The initial phase of photosynthesis, in which light energy is converted into chemical energy.

light-harvesting complex.defn: In photosynthesis, a group of different molecules that cooperate to absorb light energy and transfer it to a reaction center. Also called antenna system.

light-independent reactions.defn: Reactions that follow the light reaction and use the energy captured in the light reactions to drive the reduction of CO<sub>2</sub> to form carbohydrates.

lignin.defn: A complex, hydrophobic polyphenolic polymer in plant cell walls that crosslinks other wall polymers, strengthening the walls, especially in wood.

limbic system.defn: A group of evolutionarily primitive structures in the vertebrate telencephalon that are involved in emotions, drives, instinctive behaviors, learning, and memory.

limiting resource.defn: The required resource whose supply (or lack thereof) most strongly influences the size of a population.

lineage.defn: A series of populations, species, or genes descended from a single ancestor over evolutionary time.

lineage species concept.defn: The definition of a species as a branch on the tree of life, which has a history that starts at a speciation event and ends either at extinction or at another speciation event.

linear regression.defn: A statistical method of fitting a straight line to describe the relationship between two variables in a scatter plot.

linkage analysis.defn: Genetic analysis in which a gene and its alleles are linked to an unknown gene and its alleles and the location of the latter is determined by its co-segregating with the former in genetic crosses.

lipases.defn: Digestive enzymes that break down fats.

lipid.defn: Nonpolar, hydrophobic molecules that include fats, oils, waxes, steroids, and the phospholipids that make up biological membranes.

lipoproteins.defn: Lipids packaged inside a covering of protein so that they can be circulated in the blood.

liposome.defn: Spherical structure contained by a membrane of phospholipids. Can be used to deliver drugs to cells.

lithosphere.defn: The crust of sold rock plates that overlays the viscous mantle of Earth. The movements of the lithosphere are the source of plate tectonics.

liver.defn: A large digestive gland. In vertebrates, it secretes bile and is involved in the formation of blood.

loading.defn: In phloem, the process of transferring the products of photosynthesis, usually sugars, into sieve tubes.

loam.defn: A type of soil consisting of a mixture of sand, silt, clay, and organic matter. One of the best soil types for agriculture.

locus.defn: In genetics, a specific location on a chromosome. May be considered synonymous with gene.

logistic growth.defn: A pattern of population growth characterized by a multiplicative pattern that eventually levels off as density dependent processes slow growth at some carrying capacity

long-day plant.defn: A plant that requires long days (actually, short nights) in order to flower.

long-term depression.defn: A long-lasting decrease in the responsiveness of a neuron resulting from a period of prior stimulation.

long-term memory.defn: Information that is maintained in the brain and is accessible for long periods of time—hours to years.

long-term potentiation.defn: A long-lasting increase in the responsiveness of a neuron resulting from a period of intense stimulation.

loop of Henle.defn: Long, hairpin loop of the mammalian renal tubule that runs from the cortex down into the medulla and back to the cortex; creates a concentration gradient in the interstitial fluids in the medulla.

lophophore.defn: A U-shaped fold of the body wall with hollow, ciliated tentacles that encircles the mouth of animals in several different groups. Used for filtering prey from the surrounding water.

loss-of-function mutation.defn: A mutation that results in the loss of a functional protein.

lottery model.defn: "A hypothesis proposing that species diversity in communities is maintained by a ""lottery"" in which resources, made available by the effects of disturbance, stress, or predation, are captured at random by individuals of different species. Also called neutral model."

low-density lipoproteins.defn: "Lipoproteins that transport cholesterol around the body for use in biosynthesis and for storage; LDLs are the ""bad"" lipoproteins associated with a high risk of cardiovascular disease."

lower critical temperature.defn: The environmental temperature at which a resting endotherm must increase its metabolic rate to avoid a drop in its body temperature.

lumen.defn: The open cavity inside any tubular organ or structure, such as the gut or a renal tubule.

lung.defn: An internal organ specialized for respiratory gas exchange with air.

luteinizing hormone.defn: A gonadotropin produced by the anterior pituitary that stimulates the gonads to produce sex hormones.

lymph.defn: A fluid derived from blood and other tissues that accumulates in intercellular spaces throughout the body and is returned to the blood by the lymphatic system.

lymph node.defn: A specialized structure in the vessels of the lymphatic system. Lymph nodes contain lymphocytes, which encounter and respond to foreign cells and molecules in the lymph as it passes through the vessels.

lymphatic duct.defn: One of two large lymphatic vessels that drains lymph into a subclavian vein.

lymphocyte.defn: One of the two major classes of white blood cells; includes T cells, B cells, and other cell types important in the immune system.

lysogeny.defn: A form of viral replication in which the virus becomes incorporated into the host chromosome and remains inactive. Also called a lysogenic cycle.

lysosome.defn: A membrane-enclosed organelle originating from the Golgi apparatus and containing hydrolytic enzymes.

lysozyme.defn: An enzyme in saliva, tears, and nasal secretions that hydrolyzes bacterial cell walls.

lytic cycle.defn: A viral reproductive cycle in which the virus takes over a host cell's synthetic machinery to replicate itself, then bursts (lyses) the host cell, releasing the new viruses.

macroevolution.defn: Evolutionary changes occurring over long time spans and usually involving changes in many traits.

macroglia.defn: Non-neuronal cells of the central and peripheral nervous system that provide homeostatic functions for neurons, modulate synaptic connections, provide myelin coverings for axons, and create the blood-brain or blood-spinal cord barrier.

macromolecule.defn: A giant (molecular weight > 1,000) polymeric molecule. The macromolecules are the proteins, polysaccharides, and nucleic acids.

macronutrient.defn: In plants, a mineral element required in concentrations of at least 1 milligram per gram of plant dry matter; in animals, a mineral element required in large amounts.

macroparasites.defn: Relatively large parasite species, such as arthropods and worms.

MADS box.defn: DNA-binding domain in many plant transcription factors that is active in development.

maintenance methylase.defn: An enzyme that catalyzes the methylation of the new DNA strand when DNA is replicated.

major histocompatibility complex.defn: A complex of linked genes, with multiple alleles, that control a number of cell surface antigens that identify self and can lead to graft rejection.

malignant.defn: Pertaining to a tumor that can grow indefinitely and/or spread from the original site of growth to other locations in the body.

malnutrition.defn: A condition caused by lack of any essential nutrient.

Malpighian tubule.defn: A type of protonephridium found in insects.

mandible.defn: A crushing part of arthropod mouth parts, in mammals, the lower jaw bone, in birds the upper or lower part of the beak.

mantle.defn: (1) In mollusks, a fold of tissue that covers the organs of the visceral mass and secretes the hard shell that is typical of many mollusks. (2) In geology, Earth's crust below the solid lithospheric plates.

mark&#8211;recapture method.defn: A method of estimating population sizes of mobile organisms by capturing, marking, and releasing a sample of individuals, then capturing another sample at a later time.

mass.defn: A measure of the quantity of matter present; the greater the mass, the greater the quantity of matter.

mass extinction event.defn: A period of evolutionary history during which rates of extinction are much higher than during intervening times.

mass number.defn: The sum of the number of protons and neutrons in an atom's nucleus.

mast cells.defn: Cells, typically found in connective tissue, that release histamine in response to tissue damage.

maternal effect genes.defn: Genes coding for morphogens that determine the polarity of the egg and larva in fruit flies. Part of a developmental cascade that includes gap genes, pair rule genes, segment polarity genes, and Hox genes.

mating.defn: The joining of individuals for the purpose of reproduction.

mating type.defn: A particular strain of a species that is incapable of sexual reproduction with another member of the same strain but capable of sexual reproduction with members of other strains of the same species.
