maximum likelihood.defn: A statistical method of determining which of two or more hypotheses (such as phylogenetic trees) best fit the observed data, given an explicit model of how the data were generated.

mean.defn: The sum of all values in a sample divided by the number of observations in the sample.

measures of center.defn: Quantities that describe various aspects of the center of a group of observations.

measures of dispersion.defn: Measures that quantify the dispersion of observations in a sample of observations.

mechanically gated channel.defn: A molecular channel that opens or closes in response to mechanical force applied to the plasma membrane in which it is inserted.

mechanoreceptor.defn: A cell that is sensitive to physical movement and generates action potentials in response.

median.defn: The value at which there are equal numbers of larger and smaller observations in a sample.

medulla.defn: (1) The inner, core region of an organ, as in the adrenal medulla (adrenal gland) or the renal medulla (kidneys). (2) The portion of the brainstem that connects to the spinal cord.

medusa.defn: In cnidarians, a free-swimming, sexual life cycle stage shaped like a bell or an umbrella.

megagametophyte.defn: In heterosporous plants, the female gametophyte; produces eggs.

megakaryocytes.defn: A bone marrow cell that produces blood platelets.

megaphyll.defn: The generally large leaf of a fern, horsetail, or seed plant, with several to many veins.

megasporangia.defn: The plant structures that bear megaspores.

megaspore.defn: In plants, a haploid spore that produces a female gametophyte.

meiosis.defn: Division of a diploid nucleus to produce four haploid daughter cells. The process consists of two successive nuclear divisions with only one cycle of chromosome replication. In meiosis I, homologous chromosomes separate but retain their chromatids. The second division meiosis II, is similar to mitosis, in which chromatids separate.

Meissner's corpuscles.defn: Rapidly adapting skin mechanoreceptors sensitive to light touch and vibration. Found primarily in non-hairy skin; provide continuous information about changes in things touching the skin.

melanocyte-stimulating hormone.defn: A pituitary peptide hormone that stimulates melanocytes to produce the pigment melanin.

melatonin.defn: A hormone released by the pineal gland. Involved in photoperiodicity and circadian rhythms.

membrane.defn: A phospholipid bilayer forming a barrier that separates the internal contents of a cell from the nonbiological environment, or enclosing the organelles within a cell. The membrane regulates the molecular substances entering or leaving a cell or organelle.

membrane potential.defn: The difference in electrical charge between the inside and the outside of a cell, caused by a difference in the distribution of ions.

membranous bone.defn: A type of bone that develops by forming on a scaffold of connective tissue.

memory cells.defn: Long-lived lymphocytes produced after exposure to antigen. They persist in the body and are able to mount a rapid response to subsequent exposures to the antigen.

menopause.defn: In human females, the end of fertility and menstrual cycling.

menstrual cycle.defn: A term for the uterine cycle of humans that refers to the monthly sloughing of the uterine lining, or menses.

menstruation.defn: The process by which the endometrium breaks down, and the sloughed-off tissue, including blood, flows from the body.

meristem.defn: Plant tissue made up of undifferentiated actively dividing cells.

meristem culture.defn: A method for the asexual propagation of plants, in which pieces of shoot apical meristem are cultured to produce plantlets.

meristem identity genes.defn: In angiosperms, a group of genes whose expression initiates flower formation, probably by switching meristem cells from a vegetative to a reproductive fate.

Merkel's discs.defn: Slowly adapting skin mechanoreceptors that provide continuous information about anything touching the skin.

mesenchyme.defn: Embryonic or unspecialized cells derived from the mesoderm.

mesoderm.defn: The middle of the three embryonic germ layers first delineated during gastrulation. Gives rise to the skeleton, circulatory system, muscles, excretory system, and most of the reproductive system.

mesoglea.defn: A thick, gelatinous noncellular layer that separates the two cellular tissue layers of ctenophores, cnidarians, and scyphozoans.

mesophyll.defn: Chloroplast-containing, photosynthetic cells in the interior of leaves.

messenger RNA.defn: Transcript of a region of one of the strands of DNA; carries information (as a sequence of codons) for the synthesis of one or more proteins.

metabolism.defn: The sum total of the chemical reactions that occur in an organism, or some subset of that total (as in respiratory metabolism).

metabolome.defn: The quantitative description of all the small molecules in a cell or organism.

metagenomics.defn: The practice of analyzing DNA from environmental samples without isolating intact organisms.

metamorphosis.defn: A change occurring between one developmental stage and another, as for example from a tadpole to a frog.

metanephridia.defn: The paired excretory organs of annelids.

metapopulation.defn: A group of geographically isolated populations linked together by dispersal.

metastasis.defn: Spread of cells a tumor to regions of the body away from the primary tumor.

methylation.defn: The addition of a methyl group (—CH3) to a molecule.

micelle.defn: A particle of lipid covered with bile salts that is produced in the duodenum and facilitates digestion and absorption of lipids.

microbiome.defn: The diverse community of bacteria that lives on or within the body of an organism and is essential to bodily function.

microbiota.defn: The diverse communities of bacteria that live on or within the body.

microevolution.defn: Evolutionary changes below the species level, affecting allele frequencies.

microfilament.defn: In eukaryotic cells, a fibrous structure made up of actin monomers. Microfilaments play roles in the cytoskeleton, in cell movement, and in muscle contraction.

microgametophyte.defn: In heterosporous plants, the male gametophyte; produces sperm.

microglia.defn: Glial cells that act as macrophages and mediators of inflammatory responses in the central nervous system.

micronutrient.defn: In plants, a mineral element required in concentrations of less than 100 micrograms per gram of plant dry matter; in animals, a mineral element required in concentrations of less than 100 micrograms per day.

microparasites.defn: Parasite species too small to be seen with the naked eye, such as viruses, bacteria, protists, and fungi.

microphyll.defn: A small leaf with a single vein, found in club mosses and their relatives.

micropyle.defn: Opening in the integument(s) of a seed plant ovule through which pollen grows to reach the female gametophyte within.

microRNA.defn: A small, noncoding RNA molecule, typically about 21 bases long, that binds to mRNA to inhibit its translation.

microsporangia.defn: The plant structures that bear microspores.

microspore.defn: In plants, a haploid spore that produces a male gametophyte.

microtubules.defn: Tubular structures found in centrioles, spindle apparatus, cilia, flagella, and cytoskeleton of eukaryotic cells. These tubules play roles in the motion and maintenance of shape of eukaryotic cells.

microvilli.defn: Projections of epithelial cells, such as the cells lining the small intestine, that increase their surface area.

midbrain.defn: One of the three regions of the vertebrate brain. Part of the brainstem, it serves as a relay station for sensory signals sent to the cerebral hemispheres.

middle lamella.defn: A layer of polysaccharides that separates plant cells; a shared middle lamella lies outside the primary walls of the two cells.

migration.defn: Roundtrip movement of individuals within a population as a consequence of seasonal variation in resources.

mineral nutrients.defn: Inorganic ions required by organisms for normal growth and reproduction.

mineralization.defn: The process by which animals, bacteria, and fungi convert organic compounds into inorganic soluble nutrients.

mismatch repair.defn: A mechanism that scans DNA after it has been replicated and corrects any base-pairing mismatches.

missense mutation.defn: A change in a gene's sequence that changes the amino acid at that site in the encoded protein.

missense substitution.defn: A change in a gene from one nucleotide to another that results in a change to the corresponding amino acid in the encoded protein.

mitochondria.defn: Energy-generating organelles in eukaryotic cells that contain the enzymes of the citric acid cycle, the respiratory chain, and oxidative phosphorylation.

mitosis.defn: Nuclear division in eukaryotes leading to the formation of two daughter nuclei, each with a chromosome complement identical to that of the original nucleus.

mitosomes.defn: Reduced structures derived from mitochondria found in some organisms.

mitral valve.defn: So named because it has a similar shape to a miter (a religious headdress).

mode.defn: The most frequent value in a sample of observations.

model organisms.defn: Also known as model systems, these include the small group of species that are the subject of extensive research. They are organisms that adapt well to laboratory situations and findings from experiments on them can apply across a broad range of species. Classic examples include white mice and the fruit fly Drosophila.

moderately repetitive sequences.defn: DNA sequences repeated 10–1,000 times in the eukaryotic genome. They include the genes that code for rRNAs and tRNAs, as well as the DNA in telomeres.

molds.defn: Sac fungi composed of filamentous hyphae that do not form large ascomata.

mole.defn: A quantity of a compound whose weight in grams is numerically equal to its molecular weight expressed in atomic mass units. Avogadro's number of molecules: 6.023 × 10<sup>23</sup> molecules.

molecular clock.defn: The approximately constant rate of divergence of macromolecules from one another over evolutionary time; used to date past events in evolutionary history.

molecular evolution.defn: The scientific study of the mechanisms and consequences of the evolution of macromolecules.

molecular weight.defn: The sum of the atomic weights of the atoms in a molecule.

molecule.defn: A chemical substance made up of two or more atoms joined by covalent bonds or ionic attractions.

molting.defn: The process of shedding part or all of an outer covering, as the shedding of feathers by birds or of the entire exoskeleton by arthropods.

monoblastic.defn: Having a body derived from a single embryonic cell layer.

monocots.defn: Angiosperms with a single embryonic cotyledon; one of the two largest clades of angiosperms.

monoculture.defn: In agriculture, a large-scale planting of a single crop species.

monoecious.defn: "Pertaining to organisms in which both sexes are ""housed"" in a single individual that produces both eggs and sperm. (In some plants, these are found in different flowers within the same plant.) Examples include corn, peas, earthworms, hydras."

monohybrid cross.defn: A mating in which the parents differ with respect to the alleles of only one locus of interest.

monomer.defn: A small molecule, two or more of which can be combined to form oligomers (consisting of a few monomers) or polymers (consisting of many monomers).

monophyletic.defn: Pertaining to a group that consists of an ancestor and all of its descendants.

monosaccharide.defn: A simple sugar. Oligosaccharides and polysaccharides are made up of monosaccharides.

monosomic.defn: Pertaining to an organism with one less than the normal diploid number of chromosomes.

morphogen.defn: A diffusible substance whose concentration gradient determines a developmental pattern in embryonic animals and plants.

morphogenesis.defn: The development of form; the overall consequence of determination, differentiation, and growth.

morphological species concept.defn: The definition of a species as a group of individuals that look alike.

morphology.defn: The scientific study of organic form, including both its development and function.

mosaic development.defn: Pattern of animal embryonic development in which each blastomere contributes a specific part of the adult body.

motile.defn: Able to move from one place to another.

motor cortex.defn: The region of the cerebral cortex that contains motor neurons that directly stimulate specific muscle fibers to contract.

motor end plate.defn: The depression in the postsynaptic membrane of the neuromuscular junction where the terminals of the motor neuron sit.

motor proteins.defn: Specialized proteins that use energy to change shape and move cells or structures within cells.

motor unit.defn: A motor neuron and the muscle fibers it controls.

mucosa.defn: The first layer of the gut that lines the luminal surface.

mucus.defn: A viscous substance secreted by mucous membranes (e.g., mucosal epithelium). A barrier defense against pathogens in innate immunity in animals and a protective coating in many animal organ systems.

Muller's ratchet.defn: "The accumulation—""ratcheting up""—of deleterious mutations in the nonrecombining genomes of asexual species."

M&#252;llerian mimicry.defn: Convergence in appearance of two or more unpalatable species.

multifactorial.defn: The interaction of many genes and proteins with one or more factors in the environment. For example, cancer is a disease with multifactorial causes.

multiple fruits.defn: A fruit that develops from several carpels of multiple flowers.

multiplication rule.defn: The probability of two or more independent events occurring together is the product of their independent probabilities.

multipotent.defn: Having the ability to differentiate into a limited number of cell types.

muscle fiber.defn: A single muscle cell. In the case of skeletal muscle, a syncitial, multinucleate cell.

muscle spindles.defn: Mechanoreceptors embedded in skeletal muscle that sense changes in the length of the muscle.

muscle tissue.defn: Excitable tissue that can contract through the interactions of actin and myosin; one of the four major tissue types in multicellular animals. There are three types of muscle tissue: skeletal, smooth, and cardiac.

mutagen.defn: Any agent (e.g., a chemical, radiation) that increases the mutation rate.

mutation.defn: A change in the genetic material not caused by recombination.

mutualism.defn: A type of positive interaction in which both species benefit from the interaction, sometimes in a highly dependent and symbiotic manner.

mycelium.defn: In the fungi, a mass of hyphae.

mycorrhiza.defn: An association of the root of a plant with the mycelium of a fungus.

myelin.defn: Concentric layers of plasma membrane that form a sheath around some axons; myelin provides the axon with electrical insulation and increases the rate of transmission of action potentials.

myocardial infarction.defn: "Blockage of an artery that carries blood to the heart muscle; a ""heart attack."""

MyoD.defn: The protein encoded by the myoblast determining gene. A transcription factor involved in the differentiation of myoblasts (muscle precursor cells).

myofibril.defn: A polymeric unit of actin or myosin in a muscle.

myoglobin.defn: An oxygen-binding molecule found in muscle. Consists of a heme unit and a single globin chain; carries less oxygen than hemoglobin.

myosin.defn: One of the two contractile proteins of muscle.

myxamoeba.defn: An independent, unicellular, haploid life stage of cellular slime molds.

natural killer cell.defn: A type of lymphocyte that attacks virus-infected cells and some tumor cells as well as antibody-labeled target cells.

natural selection.defn: The differential contribution of offspring to the next generation by various genetic types belonging to the same population. The mechanism of evolution proposed by Charles Darwin.

nauplius.defn: A bilaterally symmetrical larval form typical of crustaceans.

necrosis.defn: Premature cell death caused by external agents such as toxins.

negative feedback.defn: In regulatory systems, information that decreases a regulatory response, returning the system to the set point.

negative regulation.defn: A type of gene regulation in which a gene is normally transcribed, and the binding of a repressor protein to the promoter prevents transcription.

negative-sense RNA.defn: A strand of RNA that is complementary to mRNA.

nematocyst.defn: An elaborate, threadlike structure produced by cells of jellyfishes and other cnidarians, used chiefly to paralyze and capture prey.

neoteny.defn: The retention of juvenile or larval traits by the fully developed adult organism.

nephron.defn: The functional unit of the kidney, consisting of a structure for receiving a filtrate of blood and a tubule that reabsorbs selected parts of the filtrate.

Nernst equation.defn: A mathematical statement that calculates the potential across a membrane permeable to a single type of ion that differs in concentration on the two sides of the membrane.

nerve.defn: A structure consisting of many neuronal axons and connective tissue.

nerve nets.defn: Diffuse, loosely connected aggregations of nervous tissues in certain non-bilatarian animals such as cnidarians.

nervous tissue.defn: Tissue specialized for processing and communicating information; one of the four major tissue types in multicellular animals.

net primary production.defn: The amount of energy or biomass incorporated into the tissues of primary producers after respiration.

net reproductive rate.defn: The mean number of offspring produced by an individual in a population during its lifetime.

net secondary production.defn: The amount of energy or biomass obtained from the consumption and assimilation of other organisms, taking into account respiration.

neural crest cells.defn: During vertebrate neurulation, cells that migrate outward from the neural plate and give rise to connections between the central nervous system and the rest of the body.

neural network.defn: An organized group of neurons that contains three functional categories of neurons—afferent neurons, interneurons, and efferent neurons—and is capable of processing information.

neural tube.defn: An early stage in the development of the vertebrate nervous system consisting of a hollow tube created by two opposing folds of the dorsal ectoderm along the anterior–posterior body axis.

neurohormone.defn: A chemical signal produced and released by neurons that subsequently acts as a hormone.

neuromuscular junction.defn: Synapse (point of contact) where a motor neuron axon stimulates a muscle fiber cell.

neuron.defn: A nervous system cell that can generate and conduct action potentials along an axon to a synapse with another cell.

neurotransmitter.defn: A substance produced in and released by a neuron (the presynaptic cell) that diffuses across a synapse and excites or inhibits another cell (the postsynaptic cell).

neurulation.defn: Stage in vertebrate development during which the nervous system begins to form.

neutral allele.defn: An allele that does not alter the functioning of the proteins for which it codes.

neutral theory.defn: A view of molecular evolution that postulates that most mutations do not affect the amino acid being coded for, and that such mutations accumulate in a population at rates driven by genetic drift and mutation rates.

neutron.defn: One of the three fundamental particles of matter (along with protons and electrons), with mass slightly larger than that of a proton and no electrical charge.

niche.defn: The set of physical and biological conditions a species requires to grow, reproduce, and survive.

nitrate reduction.defn: The process by which nitrate (NO<sub>3</sub><sup>−</sup>) is reduced to ammonia (NH<sub>3</sub>).

nitrification.defn: The oxidation of ammonia (NH<sub>3</sub>) to nitrate (NO<sub>3</sub><sup>−</sup>) in soil and seawater, carried out by chemoautotrophic bacteria (nitrifiers).

nitrifiers.defn: Prokaryotes that can convert ammonium into nitrate.

nitrogen fixation.defn: Conversion of atmospheric nitrogen gas (N<sub>2</sub>) into a more reactive and biologically useful form (ammonia), which makes nitrogen available to living things. Carried out by nitrogen fixers—bacteria, some of them free-living and others living within plant roots.

nitrogen fixers.defn: Organisms capable of fixing atmospheric N<sub>2</sub> to form NH<sub>3</sub>.

nitrogenase.defn: An enzyme complex found in nitrogen-fixing bacteria that mediates the stepwise reduction of atmospheric N<sub>2</sub> to ammonia and which is strongly inhibited by oxygen.

node.defn: (1) In plants, a (sometimes enlarged) point on a stem where a leaf is or was attached. (2) A region at the anterior end of the primitive grove—the site of ingression of cells during gastrulation. In mammals and birds it serves a function similar to the dorsal lip of the blastopore in amphibians.

node of Ranvier.defn: A gap in the myelin sheath covering an axon; the point where the axonal membrane can fire action potentials.

non-disjunction.defn: Failure of sister chromatids to separate in meiosis II or mitosis, or failure of homologous chromosomes to separate in meiosis I. Results in aneuploidy.

non-REM sleep.defn: A state of deep, restorative sleep characterized by high-amplitude slow waves in the EEG.

noncompetitive inhibitor.defn: A nonsubstrate that inhibits the activity of an enzyme by binding to a site other than its active site.

noncyclic electron transport.defn: In photosynthesis, the flow of electrons that forms ATP, NADPH, and O<sub>2</sub>.

nonpolar.defn: Having electric charges that are evenly balanced from one end to the other.

nonpolar covalent bond.defn: A covalent bond between atoms that has equal sharing of electrons.

nonsense mutation.defn: Change in a gene's sequence that prematurely terminates translation by changing one of its codons to a stop codon.

nonsense substitution.defn: A change in a gene from one nucleotide to another that prematurely terminates translation by changing one of its codons to a stop codon.

nonsynonymous substitution.defn: A change in a gene from one nucleotide to another that changes the amino acid specified by the corresponding codon (i.e., AGC → AGA, or serine → arginine).

nonvascular land plants.defn: All land plants that lack a vascular system.

norepinephrine.defn: A neurotransmitter found in the central nervous system and also at the postganglionic nerve endings of the sympathetic nervous system. Also called noradrenaline.

notochord.defn: A flexible rod of gelatinous material serving as a support in the embryos of all chordates and in the adults of tunicates and lancelets.

nuclear envelope.defn: A double membrane that encloses the cell nucleus.

nucleases.defn: Digestive enzymes that break down nucleic acids.

nucleic acid.defn: A polymer made up of nucleotides, specialized for the storage, transmission, and expression of genetic information. DNA and RNA are nucleic acids.

nucleic acid hybridization.defn: A technique in which a single-stranded nucleic acid probe is made that is complementary to, and binds to, a target sequence, either DNA or RNA. The resulting double-stranded molecule is a hybrid.

nucleoid.defn: The region that harbors the chromosomes of a prokaryotic cell. Unlike the eukaryotic nucleus, it is not bounded by a membrane.

nucleolus.defn: A small, generally spherical body found within the nucleus of eukaryotic cells. The site of synthesis of ribosomal RNA.

nucleoside.defn: A nucleotide without the phosphate group; a nitrogenous base attached to a sugar.

nucleosome.defn: A portion of a eukaryotic chromosome, consisting of part of the DNA molecule wrapped around a group of histone molecules, and held together by another type of histone molecule. The chromosome is made up of many nucleosomes.

nucleotide.defn: The basic chemical unit in nucleic acids, consisting of a pentose sugar, a phosphate group, and a nitrogen-containing base.

nucleus.defn: (1) In cells, the centrally located compartment of eukaryotic cells that is bounded by a double membrane and contains the chromosomes. (2) In the brain, an identifiable group of neurons that share common characteristics or functions.

null hypothesis.defn: In statistics, the premise that any differences observed in an experiment are simply the result of random differences that arise from drawing two finite samples from the same population.

nutrient.defn: A food substance; or, in the case of mineral nutrients, an inorganic element required for completion of the life cycle of an organism.

obligate.defn: A type of species interaction that is necessary to at least one species involved in the interaction.

obligate aerobe.defn: An organism that requires an oxygen atmosphere to live.

obligate anaerobe.defn: An anaerobic prokaryote that cannot survive exposure to O<sub>2</sub>.

obligate parasites.defn: Organisms that can only survive and grow in or on other living organisms, to the detriment of the host.

occipital lobe.defn: One of the four lobes of the brain's cerebral hemisphere; processes visual information.

ocean zone.defn: The marine life zone that extends from the coastal zone into open ocean. Characterized by deep water that varies in its oxygenation and relatively stable temperatures and salinities.

odorant.defn: A molecule that can bind to an olfactory receptor.

oil.defn: A triglyceride that is liquid at room temperature.

Okazaki fragments.defn: Newly formed DNA making up the lagging strand in DNA replication. DNA ligase links Okazaki fragments together to give a continuous strand.

olfactory bulb.defn: Structure in the vertebrate forebrain that receives and processes input from olfactory receptor neurons.

olfactory receptor neurons.defn: Neurons with receptors for different odorants.

oligodendrocyte.defn: A type of glial cell that myelinates axons in the central nervous system.

oligosaccharide.defn: A polymer containing a small number of monosaccharides.

omasum.defn: The third of the four chambers of the stomach in ruminants; concentrates food by water absorption before it enters the true stomach (abomasum).

ommatidia.defn: The units that make up the compound eye of some arthropods.

omnivore.defn: An organism that feeds on multiple trophic levels; also an organism that feeds on animals and primary producers.

omnivory.defn: An act of predation in which the predator is animal and the prey is an animal or a plant.

oncogene.defn: A gene that codes for a protein product that stimulates cell proliferation. Mutations in oncogenes that result in excessive cell proliferation can give rise to cancer.

one gene&#8211;one polypeptide.defn: The idea, now known to be an oversimplification, that each gene in the genome encodes only a single polypeptide—that there is a one-to-one correspondence between genes and polypeptides.

oogonium.defn: (1) In some algae and fungi, a cell in which an egg is produced. (2) In animals, the diploid progeny of a germ cell in females.

ootid.defn: In oogenesis, the daughter cell of the second meiotic division that differentiates into the mature ovum.

open circulatory system.defn: Circulatory system in which extracellular fluid leaves the vessels of the circulatory system, percolates between cells and through tissues, and then flows back into the circulatory system to be pumped out again.

operant conditioning.defn: Using a reward or a punishment to control the expression of a behavior by an animal in response to an unrelated stimulus.

operator.defn: The region of an operon that acts as the binding site for the repressor.

operon.defn: A genetic unit of transcription, typically consisting of several structural genes that are transcribed together; the operon contains at least two control regions: the promoter and the operator.

opportunity cost.defn: The sum of the benefits an animal forfeits by not being able to perform some other behavior during the time when it is performing a given behavior.

opsin.defn: The protein portion of vertebrate visual pigments; associated with the pigment molecule 11-cis-retinal.

optic chiasm.defn: Structure on the lower surface of the vertebrate brain where the two optic nerves come together.

optic nerve.defn: The nerve that carries information from the retina of the eye to the brain.

optical isomers.defn: Two molecular isomers that are mirror images of each other.

optimal foraging theory.defn: The application of a cost–benefit approach to feeding behavior to identify the fitness value of feeding choices.

oral.defn: Pertaining to the mouth, or that part of the body that contains the mouth.

orbital.defn: A region in space surrounding the atomic nucleus in which an electron is most likely to be found.

ordinal variables.defn: Categorical variables with a natural ordering, such as the grades A, B, C, D, and F.

organ.defn: A body part, such as the heart, liver, brain, root, or leaf. Organs are composed of different tissues integrated to perform a distinct function. Organs, in turn, are integrated into organ systems.

organ identity genes.defn: In angiosperms, genes that specify the different organs of the flower.

organ of Corti.defn: "Structure in the inner ear that transforms mechanical forces produced from pressure waves (""sound waves"") into action potentials that are sensed as sound."

organ system.defn: An interrelated and integrated group of tissues and organs that work together in a physiological function.

organelle.defn: Any of the membrane-enclosed structures within a eukaryotic cell. Examples include the nucleus, endoplasmic reticulum, and mitochondria.

organic fertilizers.defn: Substances added to soil to improve the soil's fertility; derived from partially decomposed plant material (compost) or animal waste (manure).

organizer.defn: Region of the early amphibian embryo that directs early embryonic development. Also known as the primary embryonic organizer.

organogenesis.defn: The formation of organs and organ systems during development.

origin of replication.defn: DNA sequence at which helicase unwinds the DNA double helix and DNA polymerase binds to initiate DNA replication.

ortholog.defn: Homologous gene whose divergence can be traced to speciation events.

osmoconformer.defn: An aquatic animal that equilibrates the osmolarity of its extracellular fluid to be the same as that of the external environment.

osmolarity.defn: The concentration of osmotically active particles in a solution.

osmoregulator.defn: An aquatic animal that actively regulates the osmolarity of its extracellular fluid.

osmosis.defn: Movement of water across a differentially permeable membrane, from one region to another region where the water potential is more negative.

ossicles.defn: "Three bones in the middle ear that transmit vibrations from tympanum to the oval window of the inner ear. Individually named the malleus (""hammer""), incus (""anvil""), and stapes (""stirrup"")."

osteoblast.defn: A cell that lays down the protein matrix of bone.

osteocyte.defn: An osteoblast that has become enclosed in lacunae within the bone it has built.

otoliths.defn: Crystals of calcium carbonate in the inner ear. Also called ear stones.

outgroup.defn: In phylogenetics, a group of organisms used as a point of reference for comparison with the groups of primary interest (the ingroup).

oval window.defn: The flexible membrane that, when moved by the bones of the middle ear, produces pressure waves in the inner ear.

ovarian cycle.defn: In human females, the monthly cycle of events by which eggs and hormones are produced.

ovary.defn: Any female organ, in plants or animals, that produces an egg.

overtopping.defn: Plant growth pattern in which one branch differentiates from and grows beyond the others.

oviduct.defn: In mammals, the tube serving to transport eggs to the uterus or to the outside of the body.

oviparity.defn: Reproduction in which eggs are released by the female and development is external to the mother's body.

ovoviviparity.defn: Pertaining to reproduction in which fertilized eggs develop and hatch within the mother's body but are not attached to the mother by means of a placenta.

ovulation.defn: Release of an egg from an ovary.

ovule.defn: In plants, a structure comprising the megasporangium and the integument, which develops into a seed after fertilization.

oxaloacetate.defn: Four-carbon salt of an acid with the formula HOOC—CO—CO—COOH that is an intermediate in metabolic pathways such as the citric acid cycle.

oxidation.defn: Relative loss of electrons in a chemical reaction; either outright removal to form an ion, or the sharing of electrons with substances having a greater affinity for them, such as oxygen. Most oxidations, including biological ones, are associated with the liberation of energy.

oxidation&#8211;reduction reaction.defn: A reaction in which one substance transfers one or more electrons to another substance.

oxidative phosphorylation.defn: ATP formation in the mitochondrion, associated with flow of electrons through the respiratory chain.

oxygenase.defn: An enzyme that catalyzes the addition of oxygen to a substrate from O<sub>2</sub>.

oxytocin.defn: A hormone released by the posterior pituitary that promotes social bonding.

P-value.defn: The calculated probability of observing a given result by chance sampling, given the null hypothesis is true.

pacemaker cells.defn: Cardiac cells that can initiate action potentials without stimulation from the nervous system, allowing the heart to initiate its own contractions.

Pacinian corpuscles.defn: Encapsulated mechanoreceptors in deep skin sensitive to pressure and vibration.

pair rule genes.defn: In Drosophila (fruit fly) development, segmentation genes that divide the early embryo into units of two segments each. Part of a developmental cascade that includes maternal effect genes, gap genes, segment polarity genes, and Hox genes.

pancreas.defn: A gland located near the stomach of vertebrates that secretes digestive enzymes into the small intestine and releases insulin into the bloodstream.

parabronchi.defn: Passages in the lungs of birds through which air flows.

paracrine.defn: Pertaining to a chemical signal, such as a hormone, that acts locally, near the site of its secretion.

parallel evolution.defn: The repeated evolution of similar traits, especially among closely related species; facilitated by conserved developmental genes.

paralog.defn: Homologous gene whose divergence can be traced to gene duplication events.

paraphyletic.defn: Pertaining to a group that consists of an ancestor and some, but not all, of its descendants.

parasite.defn: An organism that kills and/or consumes parts of an organism much larger than itself (known as its host). Parasites sometimes, but not always, kill their host.

parasitic plants.defn: Plants that obtains some of their nutrition by growing on other plants.

parasitism.defn: An act of predation in which the predator (a parasite) lives symbiotically on or in the prey (its host) and consumes only certain tissues without necessarily killing the host.

parasympathetic nervous system.defn: The division of the autonomic nervous system that works in opposition to the sympathetic nervous system.

parathyroid glands.defn: Four glands on the posterior surface of the thyroid gland that produce and release parathyroid hormone.

parathyroid hormone.defn: A hormone secreted by the parathyroid glands that stimulates osteoclast activity and raises blood calcium levels. Also called parathormone.

parenchyma.defn: A plant tissue composed of relatively unspecialized cells without secondary walls.

parent rock.defn: The soil horizon consisting of the rock that is breaking down to form the soil. Also called bedrock, or the C horizon.

parental (P) generation.defn: The individuals that mate in a genetic cross. Their offspring are the first filial (F<sub>1</sub>) generation.

parietal cells.defn: One of three types of secretory cell found in the gastric pits of the stomach wall. Parietal cells produce hydrochloric acid (HCl), creating an acidic environment that destroys many of the harmful microorganisms ingested with food.

parietal lobe.defn: One of four lobes of the cerebral hemisphere; processes complex stimuli and includes the primary somatosensory cortex.

parsimony principle.defn: Preferring the simplest among a set of plausible explanations of any phenomenon.

parthenocarpy.defn: Formation of fruit from a flower without fertilization.

parthenogenesis.defn: Production of an organism from an unfertilized egg.

partial pressures.defn: In a mixture of gasses at a specific pressure, the contribution of each gas to that total pressure.

passive transport.defn: Diffusion across a membrane; may or may not require a channel or carrier protein.

patch clamping.defn: Technique for isolating a tiny patch of membrane to allow the study of ion movement through a particular channel.

pathogen associated molecular patterns.defn: The molecules recognized by pattern recognition receptors.

pathogenesis-related (PR) protein.defn: A plant protein involved in systemic acquired resistance whose synthesis is induced in response to an infection by a pathogen such as a fungus.

pattern formation.defn: In animal embryonic development, the organization of differentiated tissues into specific structures such as wings.

pattern recognition receptors.defn: Proteins expressed by cells of the innate immune system in animals or plants that bind to molecules from pathogens containing pathogen associated molecular patterns (PAMPs).

peat.defn: Partly decomposed vegetable matter, especially of sphagnum moss, that is typically formed in acidic bogs.

pedigree.defn: The pattern of transmission of a genetic trait within a family.

penetrance.defn: The proportion of individuals with a particular genotype that show the expected phenotype.

penis.defn: An accessory sex organ of male animals that enables the male to deposit sperm in the female's reproductive tract.

pentaradial symmetry.defn: Symmetry in five or multiples of five; a feature of adult echinoderms.

pentose.defn: A sugar containing five carbon atoms.

PEP carboxylase.defn: The enzyme that combines carbon dioxide with PEP to form a 4-carbon dicarboxylic acid at the start of C<sub>4</sub> photosynthesis or of crassulacean acid metabolism (CAM).

peptidases.defn: Digestive enzymes that break down peptides.

peptide hormones.defn: Hormone molecules made up of chains of 2 to 50 amino acids (upper size arbitrary); encoded by genes and produced by translation.

peptide linkage.defn: The bond between amino acids in a protein; formed between a carboxyl group and amino group (—CO—NH—) with the loss of water molecules.

peptidoglycan.defn: The cell wall material of many bacteria, consisting of a single enormous molecule that surrounds the entire cell.

peptidyl transferase.defn: A catalytic function of the large ribosomal subunit that consists of two reactions: breaking the bond between an amino acid and its tRNA in the P site, and forming a peptide bond between that amino acid and the amino acid attached to the tRNA in the A site.

per capita birth rate.defn: In population growth models, the average number of offspring that an individual produces over some time interval.

per capita death rate.defn: In population growth models, the average individual's chance of dying in some time interval.

per capita growth rate.defn: In population models, the average individual's contribution to total population growth rate. In mathematical terms, the difference between per capita birth rate (b) and per capita death rate (d) or (b-d).

perennial.defn: A plant that survives from year to year.

perfect flower.defn: A flower with both stamens and carpels; a hermaphroditic flower.

pericycle.defn: In plant roots, tissue just within the endodermis, but outside of the root vascular tissue. Meristematic activity of pericycle cells produces lateral root primordia.

periderm.defn: The outer tissue of the secondary plant body, consisting primarily of cork.

period.defn: (1) A category in the geological time scale. (2) The duration of a single cycle in a cyclical event, such as a circadian rhythm.

periodic table.defn: The arrangement of elements in order of increasing atomic number, with vertical groupings of similar valence electrons.

peripheral membrane proteins.defn: Proteins associated with but not embedded within the plasma membrane.

peripheral nervous system.defn: The portion of the nervous system that transmits information to and from the central nervous system, consisting of neurons that extend or reside outside the brain or spinal cord and their supporting cells.

peristalsis.defn: Wavelike muscular contractions proceeding along a tubular organ, propelling the contents along the tube.

peritoneum.defn: The mesodermal lining of the body cavity in coelomate animals.

peritubular capillaries.defn: Small blood vessels that surround the renal tubules.

peroxisome.defn: An organelle that houses reactions in which toxic peroxides are formed and then converted to water.

petal.defn: In an angiosperm flower, a sterile modified leaf, nonphotosynthetic, frequently brightly colored, and often serving to attract pollinating insects.

pH.defn: The negative logarithm of the hydrogen ion concentration; a measure of the acidity of a solution. A solution with pH = 7 is said to be neutral; pH values higher than 7 characterize basic solutions, while acidic solutions have pH values less than 7.

phage therapy.defn: The therapeutic use of bacteriophages to treat pathogenic bacterial infections.

phagocyte.defn: One of two major classes of white blood cells; one of the nonspecific defenses of animals; ingests invading microorganisms by phagocytosis.

phagocytosis.defn: The process by which a cell uses its cell membrane to enclose and engulf a macromolecule or particle in the extracellular environment.

pharmacogenomics.defn: The study of how an individual's genetic makeup affects his or her response to drugs or other agents, with the goal of predicting the effectiveness of different treatment options.

pharming.defn: The use of genetically modified animals to produce medically useful products in their milk.

pharynx.defn: The part of the gut between the mouth and the esophagus.

phenotype.defn: The observable properties of an individual resulting from both genetic and environmental factors.

pheromone.defn: A chemical substance used in communication between organisms of the same species.

phloem.defn: In vascular plants, the vascular tissue that transports sugars and other solutes from sources to sinks.

phloem sap.defn: Liquid contents on the phloem tubes.

phosphatidyl inositol-bisphosphate.defn: A phospholipid in the cell membrane that is involved in cell signaling after a ligand binds to a nearby receptor.

phosphodiester linkage.defn: The connection in a nucleic acid strand, formed by linking two nucleotides.

phosphoenolpyruvate.defn: Phosphorylated salt of a three-carbon acid, formula OPO<sub>3</sub>H<sub>2</sub>—CO—CO—COOH that is an intermediate in metabolic pathways such as glycolysis.

phospholipid.defn: A lipid containing a phosphate group; an important constituent of cellular membranes.

phospholipid bilayer.defn: "The basic structural unit of biological membranes; a sheet of phospholipids two molecules thick in which the phospholipids are lined up with their hydrophobic ""tails"" packed tightly together and their hydrophilic, phosphate-containing ""heads"" facing outward. Also called lipid bilayer."

photic zone.defn: The life zone in lakes and oceans that is penetrated by light and therefore supports photosynthetic organisms.

photoautotroph.defn: An organism that obtains energy from light and carbon from carbon dioxide.

photoheterotroph.defn: An organism that obtains energy from light but must obtain its carbon from organic compounds.

photomorphogenesis.defn: In plants, a process by which physiological and developmental events are controlled by light.

photon.defn: "A quantum of visible radiation; a ""packet"" of light energy."

photoperiodism.defn: Control of an organism's physiological or behavioral responses by the length of the day or night (the photoperiod).

photophosphorylation.defn: Mechanism for ATP formation in chloroplasts in which electron transport is coupled to the transport of hydrogen ions (protons, H<sup>+</sup>) across the thylakoid membrane.

photoreceptors.defn: (1) In plants, pigments that trigger a physiological response when they absorb a photon. (2) In animals, the sensory receptor cells that sense and respond to light energy.

photorespiration.defn: Light-driven uptake of oxygen and release of carbon dioxide, the carbon being derived from the early reactions of photosynthesis.

photosynthesis.defn: Metabolic processes carried out by green plants and some microorganisms by which visible light is trapped and the energy used to synthesize compounds such as ATP and glucose.

photosynthetic lamellae.defn: The internal membrane system of the cyanobacteria.

photosystem.defn: A light-harvesting complex in the chloroplast thylakoid composed of pigments and proteins. Photosystem I absorbs light at 700 nm, passing electrons to ferredoxin and from there to NADPH. Photosystem II absorbs light at 680 nm and passes electrons to the electron transport chain in the chloroplast.

phototropin.defn: Photoreceptor proteins that mediate light reception in plants.

phototropism.defn: A directed plant growth response to light.

phycoerythrin.defn: A red protein pigment that occurs in red algae.

phylogenetic tree.defn: A graphic representation of these lines of evolutionary descent.

phylogeny.defn: The evolutionary history of a particular group of organisms or their genes.

phytoalexins.defn: Substances toxic to pathogens, produced by plants in response to fungal or bacterial infection.

phytochrome.defn: A plant pigment regulating a large number of developmental and other phenomena in plants. It has two isomers: P<sub>r</sub>, which absorbs red light, and P<sub>fr</sub>, which absorbs far red light. P<sub>fr</sub> is the active form.

phytomers.defn: In plants, the repeating modules that compose a shoot, each consisting of one or more leaves, attached to the stem at a node; an internode; and one or more axillary buds.

phytoremediation.defn: A form of bioremediation that uses plants to clean up environmental pollution.

pie chart.defn: A circular figure that displays proportions of different classes of data in an observed sample.

pigment.defn: A substance that absorbs visible light.

piloting.defn: A form of navigation in which an animal finds its way by remembering landmarks in its environment.

pilus.defn: A structure that links prokaryote cells at the beginning of conjugation.

pineal gland.defn: Gland located between the cerebral hemispheres that secretes melatonin.

pinocytosis.defn: Endocytosis by a cell of liquid containing dissolved substances.

pioneer species.defn: Species that arrive first to primary successional habitats and must deal with extreme conditions; they tend to have life history strategies that maximize population growth (see r-strategists). Also called early succession species.

pistil.defn: The structure of an angiosperm flower within which the ovules are borne. May consist of a single carpel, or of several carpels fused into a single structure. Usually differentiated into ovary, style, and stigma.

pith.defn: In plants, relatively unspecialized tissue found within a cylinder of vascular tissue.

pituitary gland.defn: A small gland attached to the base of the brain in vertebrates. Its hormones control the activities of other glands. Also known as the hypophysis.

placenta.defn: The organ in female mammals that provides for the nourishment of the fetus and elimination of the fetal waste products.

plankton.defn: Aquatic organisms that float in the water column, dependent on currents and wind for movement. Plankton include many protists, some algae, and larval animals.

planula.defn: A free-swimming, ciliated larval form typical of the cnidarians.

plaque.defn: (1) A circular clearing in a layer (lawn) of bacteria growing on the surface of a nutrient agar gel. (2) An accumulation of prokaryotic organisms on tooth enamel. Acids produced by these microorganisms cause tooth decay. (3) A region of arterial wall invaded by fibroblasts and fatty deposits.

plasma cell.defn: An antibody-secreting cell that develops from a B cell; the effector cell of the humoral immune system.

plasmid.defn: A DNA molecule distinct from the chromosome(s); that is, an extrachromosomal element; found in many bacteria. May replicate independently of the chromosome.

plasmodesmata.defn: Cytoplasmic strands connecting two adjacent plant cells.

plasmogamy.defn: The fusion of the cytoplasm of two cells.

plate tectonics.defn: The scientific study of the structure and movements of Earth's lithospheric plates, which are the cause of continental drift.

platelet.defn: A membrane-bounded body without a nucleus, arising as a fragment of a cell in the bone marrow of mammals. Important to blood-clotting action.

pleiotropy.defn: The determination of more than one character by a single gene.

pleural membrane.defn: The membrane lining the outside of the lungs and the walls of the thoracic cavity. Inflammation of these membranes is a condition known as pleurisy.

pluripotent.defn: Having the ability to form all of the cells in the body.

pneumatophores.defn: Roots that grow upward out of the water or mud to reach the air and obtain oxygen for the root systems of trees that live in swampy or tidal habitats.

podocytes.defn: Cells of Bowman's capsule of the nephron that cover the capillaries of the glomerulus, forming filtration slits.

poikilotherms.defn: Animals whose body temperatures are largely dependent on environmental temperature.

point mutation.defn: A mutation that results from the gain, loss, or substitution of a single nucleotide.

polar.defn: A molecule with separate and opposite electric charges at two ends, or poles; the water molecule (H<sub>2</sub>O) is the most prevalent example.

polar covalent bond.defn: A covalent bond in which the electrons are drawn to one nucleus more than the other, resulting in an unequal distribution of charge.

polar nuclei.defn: In angiosperms, the two nuclei in the central cell of the megagametophyte; following fertilization they give rise to the endosperm.

polarity.defn: (1) In chemistry, the property of unequal electron sharing in a covalent bond that defines a polar molecule. (2) In development, the difference between one end of an organism or structure and the other.

pole plasm.defn: Cytoplasm at one end of an insect egg that determines that the cells that form at that location will become germ cells.

pollen grain.defn: In seed plants, microscopic grains that contain the male gametophyte (microgametophyte) and gamete (microspore).

pollen tube.defn: A structure that develops from a pollen grain through which sperm are released into the megagametophyte.

pollination.defn: The process of transferring pollen from an anther to the stigma of a pistil in an angiosperm or from a strobilus to an ovule in a gymnosperm.

poly A tail.defn: A long sequence of adenine nucleotides (50–250) added after transcription to the 3' end of most eukaryotic mRNAs.

polyandry.defn: Mating system in which one female mates with multiple males.

polyculture.defn: In agriculture, a large scale planting of multiple crop species.

polygyny.defn: Mating system in which one male mates with multiple females.

polymer.defn: A large molecule made up of similar or identical subunits called monomers.

polymerase chain reaction.defn: An enzymatic technique for the rapid production of millions of copies of a particular stretch of DNA where only a small amount of the parent molecule is available.

polymorphic.defn: Coexistence in a population of two or more distinct traits.

polyp.defn: In cnidarians, a sessile, asexual life cycle stage.

polypeptide.defn: A large molecule made up of many amino acids joined by peptide linkages. Large polypeptides are called proteins.

polyphyletic.defn: Pertaining to a group that consists of multiple distantly related organisms, and does not include the common ancestor of the group.

polyploid.defn: Possessing more than two entire sets of chromosomes.

polyploidy.defn: The possession of more than two entire sets of chromosomes.

polyribosome (polysome).defn: A complex consisting of a threadlike molecule of messenger RNA and several (or many) ribosomes. The ribosomes move along the mRNA, synthesizing polypeptide chains as they proceed.

polysaccharide.defn: A macromolecule composed of many monosaccharides (simple sugars). Common examples are cellulose and starch.

pons.defn: Region of the brainstem anterior to the medulla.

population.defn: (1) In biology, any group of organisms coexisting at the same time and in the same place and capable of interbreeding with one another. (2) In statistics, a study group of interest.

population bottleneck.defn: A period during which only a few individuals of a normally large population survive.

population density.defn: The number of individuals in a population per unit of area or volume.

population dynamics.defn: The patterns and processes of change in populations over space and time.

population growth rate.defn: The rate of change in population size over time.

population growth.defn: The change in population size over time.

population size.defn: The total number of individuals in a population.

portal blood vessels.defn: Blood vessels that begin and end in capillary beds.

positional information.defn: In development, the basis of the spatial sense that induces cells to differentiate as appropriate for their location within the developing organism; often comes in the form of a morphogen gradient.

positive cooperativity.defn: Occurs when a molecule can bind several ligands and each one that binds alters the conformation of the molecule so that it can bind the next ligand more easily. The binding of four molecules of O<sub>2</sub> by hemoglobin is an example of positive cooperativity.

positive feedback.defn: In regulatory systems, information that amplifies a regulatory response, increasing the deviation of the system from the set point.

positive interaction.defn: Trophic or nontrophic interaction between two species in which one or both species benefit and neither is harmed.

positive regulation.defn: A form of gene regulation in which a regulatory macromolecule is needed to turn on the transcription of a structural gene; in its absence, transcription will not occur.

positive relationship.defn: A relationship in which two variables tend to vary among observations in the same direction.

positive selection.defn: Natural selection that acts to establish a trait that enhances survival in a population.

postabsorptive state.defn: State in which no food remains in the gut and thus no nutrients are being absorbed.

posterior.defn: Toward or pertaining to the rear.

posterior pituitary.defn: A portion of the pituitary gland derived from neural tissue; involved in the storage and release of antidiuretic hormone and oxytocin.

postzygotic isolating mechanisms.defn: Barriers to the reproductive process that occur after the union of the nuclei of two gametes.

potassium equilibrium potential.defn: The negative membrane potential that balances the tendency for K<sup>+</sup> ions to diffuse out of the cell down its concentration gradient.

potential energy.defn: Energy not doing work but with the potential to do so, such as the energy stored in chemical bonds.

power.defn: In reference to statistical tests: refers to the probability of correctly rejecting a null hypothesis when it is false.

pre-motor cortex.defn: The region of the frontal lobe of the cerebrum that is anterior to the primary motor cortex.

precursor mRNA.defn: Initial gene transcript before it is modified to produce functional mRNA. Also known as the primary transcript.

Precambrian.defn: The first and longest period of geological time, during which life originated.

precapillary sphincter.defn: A cuff of smooth muscle that can shut off the blood flow to a capillary bed.

precocial.defn: Born or hatched in a relatively advanced state that allows a high degree of independence from the parents.

predation.defn: A trophic or feeding interaction in which an individual of one species (a predator) kills and/or consumes individuals (or parts of individuals) of another species (its prey).

predator.defn: An organism that kills and/or consumes individuals (or parts of individuals) of another species (its prey).

pressure flow model.defn: An effective model for phloem transport in angiosperms. It holds that sieve element transport is driven by an osmotically generated pressure gradient between source and sink.

pressure potential.defn: The hydrostatic pressure of an enclosed solution in excess of the surrounding atmospheric pressure.

prevailing winds.defn: The circulation of air (wind) that moves across the Earth's surface in a predominately single direction.

prey.defn: An organism killed and/or consumed by a predator as an energy source.

prezygotic isolating mechanisms.defn: Barriers to the reproductive process that occur before the union of the nuclei of two gametes

primary active transport.defn: Active transport in which ATP is hydrolyzed, yielding the energy required to transport an ion or molecule against its concentration gradient.

primary bronchi.defn: The first airways that branch off of the trachea.

primary cell wall.defn: In plant cells, a structure that forms at the middle lamella after cytokinesis, made up of cellulose microfibrils, hemicelluloses, and pectins.

primary consumer.defn: An organism (herbivore) that feeds on primary producers.

primary endosymbiosis.defn: The engulfment of a cyanobacterium by a larger eukaryotic cell that gave rise to the first photosynthetic eukaryotes with chloroplasts.

primary growth.defn: In plants, growth that is characterized by the lengthening of roots and shoots and by the proliferation of new roots and shoots through branching.

primary immune response.defn: The first response of the immune system to an antigen, involving recognition by lymphocytes and the production of effector cells and memory cells.

primary lysosomes.defn: A lysosome before fusion with an endosome.

primary meristem.defn: Meristem that produces the tissues of the primary plant body.

primary oocyte.defn: The diploid progeny of an oogonium. In many species, a primary oocyte enters prophase of the first meiotic division, then remains in developmental arrest for a long time before resuming meiosis to form a secondary oocyte and a polar body.

primary producer.defn: A photosynthetic or chemosynthetic organism that synthesizes complex organic molecules from simple inorganic ones.

primary sex determination.defn: Genetic determination of gametic sex, male or female.

primary spermatocyte.defn: The diploid progeny of a spermatogonium; undergoes the first meiotic division to form secondary spermatocytes.

primary structure.defn: The specific sequence of amino acids in a protein.

primary succession.defn: Succession of ecological communities that begins in an area devoid of life, such as on recently exposed glacial till or lava flows.

primase.defn: An enzyme that catalyzes the synthesis of a primer for DNA replication.

primer.defn: Strand of nucleic acid, usually RNA, that is the necessary starting material for the synthesis of a new DNA strand, which is synthesized from the 3' end of the primer.

primitive streak.defn: A midline ridge that forms in the avian blastula that will become the blastopore.

probability.defn: A numerical quantity that expresses the likelihood of an event occurring on a scale from 0 (no chance of the event) to 1 (certainty of the event).

probe.defn: A segment of single-stranded nucleic acid used to identify DNA molecules containing the complementary sequence.

proboscis.defn: An elongated nose or sucking mouthpart that is typically tubular and flexible.

procambium.defn: Primary meristem that produces the vascular tissue.

processive.defn: Pertaining to an enzyme that catalyzes many reactions each time it binds to a substrate, as DNA polymerase does during DNA replication.

production efficiency.defn: The proportion of assimilated biomass used to produce new consumer biomass or net secondary production.

products.defn: The molecules that result from the completion of a chemical reaction.

progesterone.defn: A female sex hormone that maintains pregnancy.

prokaryotes.defn: Unicellular organisms that do not have nuclei or other membrane-enclosed organelles. Includes Bacteria and Archaea.

promoter.defn: A DNA sequence to which RNA polymerase binds to initiate transcription.

proofreading.defn: During DNA replication, a mechanism that excises a base that is incorrectly inserted according to the template (e.g., an A opposite a template G) and inserts the correct base (e.g., C opposite template G).

prop roots.defn: Adventitious roots in some monocots that function as supports for the shoot.

prophage.defn: The noninfectious units that are linked with the chromosomes of the host bacteria and multiply with them but do not cause dissolution of the cell. Prophage can later enter into the lytic phase to complete the virus life cycle.

prostaglandin.defn: Any one of a group of specialized lipids with hormone-like functions. It is not clear that they act at any considerable distance from the site of their production.

prostate gland.defn: In male humans, surrounds the urethra at its junction with the vas deferens; supplies an acid-neutralizing fluid to the semen.

proteases.defn: Digestive enzymes that break the bonds between adjacent amino acids in proteins.

proteasome.defn: In the eukaryotic cytoplasm, a huge protein structure that binds to and digests cellular proteins that have been tagged by ubiquitin.

protected areas.defn: An area in which habitat loss or degradation by human activity is restricted or prohibited.

protein.defn: Long-chain polymer of amino acids with twenty different common side chains. Occurs with its polymer chain extended in fibrous proteins, or coiled into a compact macromolecule in enzymes and other globular proteins. The component amino acids are encoded in the triplets of messenger RNA, and proteins are the products of genes.

protein hormones.defn: Large hormone molecules made up of chains of generally greater than 50 amino acids; encoded by genes and produced by translation.

protein kinase.defn: An enzyme that catalyzes the addition of a phosphate group from ATP to a target protein.

protein kinase cascade.defn: A series of reactions in response to a molecular signal, in which a series of protein kinases activate one another in sequence, amplifying the signal at each step.

proteoglycan.defn: A glycoprotein containing a protein core with attached long, linear carbohydrate chains.

proteolysis.defn: An enzymatic digestion of a protein or polypeptide.

proteome.defn: The complete set of proteins that can be made by an organism. Because of alternative splicing of pre-mRNA, the number of proteins that can be made is usually much larger than the number of protein-coding genes present in the organism's genome.

prothoracic gland.defn: A gland in insects that secretes the molting hormone ecdysone.

prothoracicotropic hormone.defn: An insect hormone that controls the prothoracic gland.

prothrombin.defn: The inactive form of thrombin, an enzyme involved in blood clotting.

protocells.defn: A self-organized sphere of lipids proposed as a stepping-stone to the origin of life.

protoderm.defn: Primary meristem that gives rise to the plant epidermis.

proton.defn: (1) A subatomic particle with a single positive charge. The number of protons in the nucleus of an atom determine its element. (2) A hydrogen ion, H<sup>+</sup>.

proton pump.defn: An active transport system that uses ATP energy to move hydrogen ions across a membrane, generating an electric potential.

proton-motive force.defn: Force generated across a membrane having two components: a chemical potential (difference in proton concentration) plus an electrical potential due to the electrostatic charge on the proton.

protonephridium.defn: The excretory organ of flatworms, made up of a tubule and a flame cell.

provirus.defn: Double+stranded DNA made by a virus that is integrated into the host's chromosome and contains promoters that are recognized by the host cell's transcription apparatus.

proximal convoluted tubule.defn: The initial segment of a renal tubule, closest to the glomerulus.

proximate causes.defn: The immediate genetic, physiological, neurological, and developmental mechanisms responsible for a behavior or morphology.

pseudocoelomate.defn: Having a body cavity, called a pseudocoel, consisting of a fluid-filled space in which many of the internal organs are suspended, but which is enclosed by mesoderm only on its outside.

pseudogene.defn: A DNA segment that is homologous to a functional gene but is not expressed because of changes to its sequence or changes to its location in the genome.

pseudoplasmodium.defn: An aggregation of myxamoebas that resembles a plasmodium.

pulmonary arteries.defn: In vertebrates, blood vessels that carry blood from the heart to the lungs.

pulmonary circuit.defn: The portion of the circulatory system by which blood is pumped from the heart to the lungs or gills for oxygenation and back to the heart for distribution.

pulmonary valve.defn: A one-way valve between the right ventricle of the heart and the pulmonary artery that prevents backflow of blood into the ventricle when it relaxes.

pulmonary veins.defn: Veins that return oxygenated blood from the lungs to the left atrium.

pulp cavity.defn: The space in the interior of the tooth that contains blood vessels, nerves, and dentine-producing cells.

Punnett square.defn: Method of predicting the results of a genetic cross by arranging the gametes of each parent at the edges of a square.

pupil.defn: The opening in the vertebrate eye through which light passes.

purifying selection.defn: The elimination by natural selection of detrimental characters from a population.

purine.defn: One of the two types of nitrogenous bases in nucleic acids. Each of the purines—adenine and guanine—pairs with a specific pyrimidine.

Purkinje fibers.defn: Specialized heart muscle cells that conduct excitation throughout the ventricular muscle.

pyrimidine.defn: One of the two types of nitrogenous bases in nucleic acids. Each of the pyrimidines—cytosine, thymine, and uracil—pairs with a specific purine.

pyrogen.defn: Molecule that produces a rise in body temperature (fever); may be produced by an invading pathogen or by cells of the immune system in response to infection.

pyruvate.defn: The ionized form of pyruvic acid, a three-carbon acid; the end product of glycolysis and the raw material for the citric acid cycle.

Q<sub>10</sub>.defn: A value that compares the rate of a biochemical process or reaction over 10°C temperature ranges. A process that is not temperature-sensitive has a Q<sub>10</sub> of 1; values of 2 or 3 mean the reaction speeds up as temperature increases.

quadrat.defn: A four sided measurement area of any size used to count the individuals within the area.

qualitative.defn: Based on observation of an unmeasured quality of a trait, as in brown vs. blue.

quantitative.defn: Based on numerical values obtained by measurement, as in quantitative data.

quantitative trait loci.defn: A set of genes determining a complex character (trait) that exhibits quantitative variation (variation in amount rather than in kind).

quantitative variables.defn: Variables that are measured by a quantity, as opposed to ones that differ only in a quality.

quaternary structure.defn: The specific three-dimensional arrangement of protein subunits.

quorum sensing.defn: The use of chemical communication signals to trigger density-linked activities such as biofilm formation in prokaryotes.

R group.defn: The distinguishing group of atoms of a particular amino acid; also known as a side chain.

r-strategist.defn: A species whose life history strategy allows for a high intrinsic rate of population increase (r).

radial cleavage.defn: Embryonic development in which the planes of cell division are parallel and perpendicular to the animal-vegetal axis of the embryo.

radial symmetry.defn: The condition in which any two halves of a body are mirror images of each other, providing the cut passes through the center; a cylinder cut lengthwise down its center displays this form of symmetry.

radiation.defn: The transfer of heat from warmer objects to cooler ones via the exchange of infrared radiation.

radioactive decay.defn: Spontaneous disintegration of a substance with the emission of ionizing radiation.

radioisotope.defn: A radioactive isotope of an element. Examples are carbon-14 (<sup>14</sup>C) and hydrogen-3, or tritium (<sup>3</sup>H).

radiometric dating.defn: A method for determining the age of objects such as fossils and rocks based on the decay rates of radioactive isotopes.

radula.defn: A rasplike structure used for scraping food particles off a surface.

rain shadow.defn: The relatively dry area on the down-wind side of a mountain range.

random dispersion.defn: The spatial arrangement of individuals within a population, characterized by random spatial patterns.

range.defn: The largest minus the smallest observed value for a variable in a sample.

rapid eye movement (REM) sleep.defn: A sleep state characterized by vivid dreams, skeletal muscle relaxation, and rapid eye movements.

reactant.defn: A chemical substance that enters into a chemical reaction with another substance.

reaction center.defn: A group of electron transfer proteins that receive energy from light-absorbing pigments and convert it to chemical energy by redox reactions.

realized niche.defn: A species' niche as defined by its interactions with other species.

receptive field.defn: The area of visual space that activates a particular cell in the visual system.

receptor potential.defn: The change in the resting potential of a sensory cell when it is stimulated.

receptor protein.defn: A protein that can bind to a specific molecule, or detect a specific stimulus, within the cell or in the cell's external environment.

receptor-mediated endocytosis.defn: Endocytosis initiated by macromolecular binding to a specific membrane receptor.

recessive.defn: In genetics, an allele that does not determine phenotype in the presence of a dominant allele.

recombinant chromatid.defn: In meiosis, a chromatid after crossing over that contains part of a sister chromatid, typically having exchanged that part with the sister chromatid.

recombinant DNA.defn: A DNA molecule made in the laboratory that is derived from two or more genetic sources.

recombinant frequency.defn: The proportion of offspring of a genetic cross that have phenotypes different from the parental phenotypes due to crossing over between linked genes during gamete formation.

rectum.defn: The terminal portion of the gut, ending at the anus.

redox reaction.defn: A chemical reaction in which one reactant is oxidized (loses electrons) and the other is reduced (gains electrons). Short for reduction–oxidation reaction.

reduction.defn: Gain of electrons by a chemical reactant.

refractory period.defn: The time interval after an action potential during which another action potential cannot be elicited from an excitable membrane.

regeneration.defn: The development of a complete individual from a fragment of an organism.

regional species pool.defn: All the species that are limited to a geographic region; sometimes called gamma diversity.

regular (uniform) dispersion.defn: The spatial arrangement of individuals within a population, characterized by evenly spaced individuals.

regulated specification.defn: Determination of cell fates due to signals mostly received from neighboring cells.

regulative development.defn: A pattern of animal embryonic development in which the fates of the first blastomeres are not absolutely fixed.

regulatory sequence.defn: A DNA sequence to which the protein product of a regulatory gene binds.

regulatory system.defn: A system that uses feedback information to maintain a physiological function or parameter at an optimal level.

regulatory T cells.defn: The class of T cells that mediates tolerance to self antigens.

reinforcement.defn: The evolution of enhanced reproductive isolation between populations due to natural selection for greater isolation.

releaser.defn: Sensory stimulus that triggers performance of a stereotyped behavior pattern.

renal artery.defn: The main artery supplying the kidney.

renal pyramids.defn: Tissue of the renal medulla that projects into and releases urine into the renal pelvis which is drained by the ureter.

renal tubule.defn: A structural unit of the kidney that collects filtrate from the blood, reabsorbs specific ions, nutrients, and water and returns them to the blood, and concentrates excess ions and waste products such as urea for excretion from the body.

renal vein.defn: The main vein carrying blood from the kidney.

renin.defn: An enzyme released from the kidneys in response to a drop in the glomerular filtration rate. Together with angiotensin converting enzyme, converts an inactive protein in the blood into angiotensin.

replication fork.defn: A point at which a DNA molecule is replicating. The fork forms by the unwinding of the parent molecule.

replicon.defn: A region of DNA replicated from a single origin of replication.

reporter gene.defn: A genetic marker included in recombinant DNA to indicate the presence of the recombinant DNA in a host cell.

repressor.defn: A protein encoded by a regulatory gene that can bind to a promoter and prevent transcription of the associated gene.

reproductive isolation.defn: Condition in which two divergent populations are no longer exchanging genes. Can lead to speciation.

reproductive signal.defn: In cell biology, the internal or external signal that causes a cell to initiate its mitotic or meiotic cell division cycle.

residual volume.defn: In tidal ventilation, the dead space that remains in the lungs at the end of exhalation.

residuals.defn: The deviations, along the y-axis from the linear regression line, of individual observations in a bivariate scatter plot.

resistance (R) genes.defn: Plant genes that confer resistance to specific strains of pathogens.

resource.defn: Components of the environment such as food, water, light, and space that are required by all species.

resource partitioning.defn: A situation in which species share limiting resources by using them in different ways, thereby allowing them to coexist.

resource-mediated coexistence.defn: A type of coexistence among competitors in which factors such as disturbance, stress, or predation that act on the dominant competitor, allow inferior competitors access to limiting resources.

respiratory chain.defn: The terminal reactions of cellular respiration, in which electrons are passed from NAD or FAD, through a series of intermediate carriers, to molecular oxygen, with the concomitant production of ATP.

respiratory gases.defn: Oxygen (O<sub>2</sub>) and carbon dioxide (CO<sub>2</sub>); the gases that an animal must exchange between its internal body fluids and the outside medium (air or water).

resting potential.defn: The membrane potential of a living cell at rest. In cells at rest, the interior is negative to the exterior.

restoration ecology.defn: The science and practice of restoring damaged or degraded ecosystems by active human intervention.

restriction digestion.defn: An enzymatic reaction in which a molecule of DNA is fully cleaved by a restriction enzyme.

restriction enzyme.defn: Any of a type of enzyme that cleaves double-stranded DNA at specific sites; extensively used in recombinant DNA technology. Also called a restriction endonuclease.

restriction point.defn: The specific time during G1 of the cell cycle at which the cell becomes committed to undergo the rest of the cell cycle.

restriction site.defn: A specific DNA base sequence that is recognized and acted on by a restriction endonuclease.

reticular-activating system.defn: A central region of the vertebrate brainstem that includes complex fiber tracts conveying neural signals between the forebrain and the spinal cord, with collateral fibers to a variety of nuclei that are involved in autonomic functions, including arousal from sleep.

reticulation.defn: In a phylogenetic tree, a combining of lineages (through hybridization of gene capture, for example).

reticulum.defn: The second of the four chambers of the ruminant stomach. Along with the rumen, it is where food is partially digested with the assistance of gut bacteria.

retina.defn: The light-sensitive layer of cells in the vertebrate or cephalopod eye.

retrovirus.defn: An RNA virus that contains reverse transcriptase. Its RNA serves as a template for cDNA production, and the cDNA is integrated into a chromosome of the host cell.

reverse transcriptase.defn: An enzyme that catalyzes the production of DNA (cDNA), using RNA as a template; essential to the reproduction of retroviruses.

reverse transcription.defn: Production of DNA using an RNA template.

reversible reaction.defn: A chemical transformation that can occur in either direction, so that reactants become products and vice versa.

reversion mutation.defn: A second- or third-round mutation that reverts the DNA to its original sequence or to a new sequence that results in a non-mutant phenotype.

rhizoids.defn: Hairlike extensions of cells in mosses, liverworts, and a few vascular plants that serve the same function as roots and root hairs in vascular plants. The term is also applied to branched, rootlike extensions of some fungi and algae.

rhizome.defn: An underground stem (as opposed to a root) that runs horizontally beneath the ground.

rhodopsin.defn: A vertebrate visual pigment involved in transducing photons of light into changes in the membrane potential of certain photoreceptor cells.

ribose.defn: A five-carbon sugar in nucleotides and RNA.

ribosomal RNA.defn: Several species of RNA that are incorporated into the ribosome. Involved in peptide bond formation.

ribosome.defn: A small particle in the cell that is the site of protein synthesis.

ribozyme.defn: An RNA molecule with catalytic activity.

risk cost.defn: The increased chance of being injured or killed as a result of performing a behavior, compared to resting.

RNA (ribonucleic acid).defn: An often single-stranded nucleic acid whose nucleotides use ribose rather than deoxyribose and in which the base uracil replaces thymine found in DNA. Serves as genome from some viruses. (See ribosomal RNA, transfer RNA, messenger RNA, and ribozyme.)

RNA interference.defn: A mechanism for reducing mRNA translation whereby a double-stranded RNA, made by the cell or synthetically, is processed into a small, single-stranded RNA, whose binding to a target mRNA results in the latter's breakdown.

RNA polymerase.defn: An enzyme that catalyzes the formation of RNA from a DNA template.

RNA processing.defn: Modification of RNA primary transcripts, for example splicing out of introns.
