RNA splicing.defn: The last stage of RNA processing in eukaryotes, in which the transcripts of introns are excised through the action of small nuclear ribonucleoprotein particles (snRNP).

rod cells.defn: Light-sensitive cells in the vertebrate retina; these sensory receptor cells are sensitive in extremely dim light and are responsible for dim light, black and white vision.

root.defn: The organ responsible for anchoring the plant in the soil, absorbing water and minerals, and producing certain hormones. Some roots are storage organs.

root apical meristem.defn: Undifferentiated tissue at the apex of the root that gives rise to the organs of the root.

root cap.defn: A thimble-shaped mass of cells, produced by the root apical meristem, that protects the meristem; the organ that perceives the gravitational stimulus in root gravitropism.

root hair.defn: A long, thin process from a root epidermal cell that absorbs water and minerals from the soil solution.

root nodule.defn: A swelling on the root of a leguminous plant, such as the soybean, that contains nitrogen-fixing Rhizobium bacteria.

root system.defn: The organ system that anchors a plant in place, absorbs water and dissolved minerals, and may store products of photosynthesis from the shoot system.

rotational cleavage.defn: The form of complete cleavage that occurs in mammals. The first cleavage plain is parallel to the animal–vegetal axis and the two second cleavage planes are at right angles to each other.

rough endoplasmic reticulum.defn: The portion of the endoplasmic reticulum whose outer surface has attached ribosomes.

round window.defn: A flexible membrane at the end of the lower canal of the cochlea in the human ear.

RT-PCR.defn: A laboratory manipulation of RNA in which the RNA is first incubated with reverse transcriptase (RT) to make cDNA and then the cDNA amplified for analysis by the polymerase chain reaction (PCR).

rubisco.defn: Contraction of ribulose bisphosphate carboxylase/oxygenase, the enzyme that combines carbon dioxide or oxygen with ribulose bisphosphate to catalyze the first step of photosynthetic carbon fixation or photorespiration, respectively.

Ruffini endings.defn: Slowly adapting stretch receptor in the skin.

rumen.defn: The first of the four chambers of the ruminant stomach. Along with the reticulum, it is where food is partially digested with the assistance of gut bacteria.

ruminant.defn: Herbivorous, cud-chewing mammals such as cows or sheep, characterized by a stomach that consists of four compartments: the rumen, reticulum, omasum, and abomasum.

S phase.defn: In the cell cycle, the stage of interphase during which DNA is replicated.

salt glands.defn: Glands on the leaves of some halophytic plants that secrete salt, thereby ridding the plants of excess salt.

saltatory conduction.defn: "The rapid conduction of action potentials in myelinated axons; so called because action potentials appear to ""jump"" between nodes of Ranvier along the axon."

sample.defn: A set of observations made from a population.

saprobe.defn: An organism (usually a bacterium or fungus) that obtains its carbon and energy by absorbing nutrients from dead organic matter. Also called a saprotroph.

sarcomere.defn: The contractile unit of a skeletal muscle.

sarcoplasm.defn: The cytoplasm of a muscle cell.

sarcoplasmic reticulum.defn: The endoplasmic reticulum of a muscle cell.

saturated fatty acid.defn: A fatty acid in which all the bonds between carbon atoms in the hydrocarbon chain are single bonds—that is, all the bonds are saturated with hydrogen atoms.

scatter plot.defn: A figure that displays the values of observations for two variables along perpendicular axes.

scavenger.defn: An animal that eats larger dead organisms but is not typically considered a detritivore.

Schwann cell.defn: A type of glial cell that myelinates axons in the peripheral nervous system.

scion.defn: In horticulture, the bud or stem from one plant that is grafted to a root or root-bearing stem of another plant (the stock).

sclera.defn: The white outer layer of the eyeball continuous with the cornea.

sclereid.defn: One of the principle types of cells in sclerenchyma.

scrotum.defn: In most mammals, a pouch outside the body cavity that contains the testes.

second law of thermodynamics.defn: The principle that when energy is converted from one form to another, some of that energy becomes unavailable for doing work.

second messenger.defn: A compound, such as cAMP, that is released within a target cell after a hormone (the first messenger) has bound to a surface receptor on a cell; the second messenger triggers further reactions within the cell.

second polar body.defn: In oogenesis, the daughter cell of the second meiotic division that subsequently degenerates.

secondary active transport.defn: A form of active transport that does not use ATP as an energy source; rather, transport is coupled to ion diffusion down a concentration gradient established by primary active transport.

secondary bronchi.defn: The airways branching off of the primary bronchi.

secondary cell wall.defn: A thick, cellulosic structure internal to the primary cell wall formed in some plant cells after cell expansion stops.

secondary consumer.defn: An organism (carnivore) that feeds on herbivores or primary consumers.

secondary endosymbiosis.defn: The engulfment of a photosynthetic eukaryote by another eukaryotic cell that gave rise to certain groups of photosynthetic eukaryotes (e.g., euglenids).

secondary growth.defn: In plants, growth that contributes to an increase in girth.

secondary immune response.defn: A rapid and intense response to a second or subsequent exposure to an antigen, initiated by memory cells.

secondary lysosome.defn: Membrane-enclosed organelle formed by the fusion of a primary lysosome with a phagosome, in which macromolecules taken up by phagocytosis are hydrolyzed into their monomers.

secondary metabolite.defn: A compound synthesized by a plant that is not needed for basic cellular metabolism. Typically has an antiherbivore or antiparasite function.

secondary oocyte.defn: In oogenesis, the daughter cell of the first meiotic division that receives almost all the cytoplasm.

secondary production.defn: Source of energy for organisms and ecosystems that is derived from the consumption of organic compounds produced by other organisms.

secondary sex characteristics.defn: Outward expression of sex determination in organs and tissues, such a body hair and stature in humans.

secondary spermatocyte.defn: One of the products of the first meiotic division of a primary spermatocyte.

secondary structure.defn: Of a protein, localized regularities of structure, such as the α helix and the β pleated sheet.

secondary succession.defn: The reestablishment of a community when most, but not all, organisms have been destroyed.

secretin.defn: A peptide hormone secreted by the upper region of the small intestine when acidic chyme is present. Stimulates the pancreatic duct to secrete bicarbonate ions.

sedimentary rock.defn: Rock formed by the accumulation of sediment grains on the bottom of a body of water. Often contain stratified fossils that allow geologists and biologists to date evolutionary events relative to each other.

seed.defn: A fertilized, ripened ovule of a gymnosperm or angiosperm. Consists of the embryo, nutritive tissue, and a seed coat.

seedling.defn: A plant that has just completed the process of germination.

segment polarity genes.defn: In Drosophila (fruit fly) development, segmentation genes that determine the boundaries and anterior–posterior organization of individual segments. Part of a developmental cascade that includes maternal effect genes, gap genes, pair rule genes, and Hox genes.

segmentation.defn: Division of an animal body into segments.

segmentation genes.defn: Genes that determine the number and polarity of body segments.

segregation.defn: In genetics, the separation of alleles, or of homologous chromosomes, from each other during meiosis so that each of the haploid daughter nuclei produced contains one or the other member of the pair found in the diploid parent cell, but never both. This principle was articulated by Mendel as his first law.

selectable marker.defn: A gene, such as one encoding resistance to an antibiotic, that can be used to identify (select) cells that contain recombinant DNA from among a large population of untransformed cells.

selective permeability.defn: Allowing certain substances to pass through while other substances are excluded; a characteristic of membranes.

self-incompatability.defn: In plants, the possession of mechanisms that prevent self-fertilization.

semelparity.defn: Reproducing only once in a lifetime.

semen.defn: The thick, whitish liquid produced by the male reproductive system in mammals, containing the sperm.

semicircular canals.defn: Three canals in the human inner ear that form part of the vestibular system.

semiconservative replication.defn: The way in which DNA is synthesized. Each of the two partner strands in a double helix acts as a template for a new partner strand. Hence, after replication, each double helix consists of one old and one new strand.

seminal vesicles.defn: Male accessory sex glands that contribute most of the volume of the semen including mucus, fibrinogen, and fructose.

seminiferous tubules.defn: The tubules within the testes within which sperm production occurs.

sensitive period.defn: The life stage during which some particular type of learning must take place, or during which it occurs much more easily than at other times. Typical of song learning among birds. Also known as the critical period.

sensor.defn: Cell that is responsive to a particular type of physical or chemical stimulation.

sensory mechanisms.defn: The means by which internal or external stimuli are converted into neural signals.

sensory organs.defn: Structures that convert types of internal or environmental energy into electrical signals used by the nervous system.

sensory system.defn: A set of organs and tissues for detecting a stimulus; consists of sensory cells, the associated structures, and the neural networks that process the information.

sensory transduction.defn: The transformation of environmental stimuli or information into neural signals.

sepal.defn: One of the outermost structures of the flower, usually protective in function and enclosing the rest of the flower in the bud stage.

septate.defn: Divided, as by walls or partitions.

septum.defn: (1) A partition or cross-wall appearing in the hyphae of some fungi. (2) The bony structure dividing the nasal passages.

sequence alignment.defn: A method of identifying homologous positions in DNA or amino acid sequences by pinpointing the locations of deletions and insertions that have occurred since two (or more) organisms diverged from a common ancestor.

Sertoli cells.defn: Cells in the seminiferous tubules of the testes that nurture the developing sperm.

sessile.defn: Permanently attached; not able to move from one place to another.

set point.defn: In a regulatory system, the threshold sensitivity to the feedback stimulus.

sex chromosome.defn: In organisms with a chromosomal mechanism of sex determination, one of the chromosomes involved in sex determination (in humans and many other animals, these are the X and Y chromosomes).

sex pilus.defn: A thin connection between two bacteria through which genetic material passes during conjugation.

sex-linked.defn: Gene that is carried on a sex chromosome, such as the X chromosome in mammals.

sex-linked inheritance.defn: Pattern of inheritance characteristic of genes located on the sex chromosomes of organisms having a chromosomal mechanism for sex determination.

sexual reproduction.defn: Reproduction involving the union of gametes.

sexual selection.defn: Selection by one sex of characteristics in individuals of the opposite sex. Also, the favoring of characteristics in one sex as a result of competition among individuals of that sex for mates.

Shannon index.defn: The quantitative index most commonly used to describe species diversity that includes measures of both species richness and species evenness.

shoot apical meristem.defn: Undifferentiated tissue at the apex of the shoot that gives rise to the organs of the shoot.

shoot system.defn: In plants, the organ system consisting of the leaves, stem(s), and flowers.

short tandem repeats.defn: Short (1–5 base pairs), moderately repetitive sequences of DNA. The number of copies of an STR at a particular location varies between individuals and is inherited.

short-day plant.defn: A plant that flowers when nights are longer than a critical length specific for that plant's species.

short-term memory.defn: Information that is maintained in the brain and can be accessed for a short period of time—seconds to minutes.

sieve tube element.defn: The characteristic cell of the phloem in angiosperms, which contains cytoplasm but relatively few organelles, and whose end walls (sieve plates) contain pores that form connections with neighboring cells.

sigma factor.defn: In prokaryotes, a protein that binds to RNA polymerase, allowing the complex to bind to and stimulate the transcription of a specific class of genes (e.g., those involved in sporulation).

signal sequence.defn: The sequence within a protein that directs the protein to a particular organelle.

signal transduction pathway.defn: The series of biochemical steps whereby a stimulus to a cell (such as a hormone or neurotransmitter binding to a receptor) is translated into a response of the cell.

signaling mechanisms.defn: The means of transferring information between cells, organs, or organisms.

significance level.defn: A particular threshold of making a Type I error (incorrectly rejecting a true null hypothesis) in a statistical test, selected a priori by the investigator.

silencer.defn: A gene sequence binding transcription factors that repress transcription.

silent mutation.defn: A change in a gene's sequence that has no effect on the amino acid sequence of a protein either because it occurs in noncoding DNA or because it does not change the amino acid specified by the corresponding codon.

similarity matrix.defn: A matrix used to compare the degree of divergence among pairs of objects. For molecular sequences, constructed by summing the number or percentage of nucleotides or amino acids that are identical in each pair of sequences.

simple diffusion.defn: Diffusion that does not involve a direct input of energy or assistance by carrier proteins.

simple fruit.defn: A fruit that develops from a single carpel in a single flower.

single nucleotide polymorphisms.defn: Inherited variations in a single nucleotide base in DNA that differ between individuals.

single-strand binding protein.defn: In DNA replication, a protein that binds to single strands of DNA after they have been separated from each other, keeping the two strands separate for replication.

sink.defn: In plants, any organ that imports the products of photosynthesis, such as roots, developing fruits, and immature leaves.

sink populations.defn: Populations that receive more immigrants from other populations within a metapopulation than they produce.

sinoatrial node.defn: The pacemaker of the mammalian heart.

sinus venosus.defn: The first chamber of the heart of fish that opens into the atrium.

small interfering RNAs.defn: Short, double-stranded RNA molecules used in RNA interference.

sister chromatid.defn: Each of a pair of newly replicated chromatids.

sister clades.defn: Two clades that are each other's closest relatives.

sister species.defn: Two species that are each other's closest relatives.

skeletal muscle.defn: A type of muscle tissue characterized by multinucleated cells containing highly ordered arrangements of actin and myosin microfilaments. Also called striated muscle.

skeletal systems.defn: Organ systems that provide rigid supports—skeletons—against which muscles can pull to create directed movements.

sliding DNA clamp.defn: Protein complex that keeps DNA polymerase bound to DNA during replication.

sliding filament model.defn: Mechanism of muscle contraction based on the formation and breaking of crossbridges between actin and myosin filaments, causing the filaments to slide together.

slow-twitch fibers.defn: Skeletal muscle fibers specialized for sustained aerobic work; contain myoglobin and abundant mitochondria, and are well-supplied with blood vessels. Also called oxidative or red muscle fibers.

small intestine.defn: The portion of the gut between the stomach and the colon; consists of the duodenum, the jejunum, and the ileum.

smooth endoplasmic reticulum.defn: Portion of the endoplasmic reticulum that lacks ribosomes and has a tubular appearance.

smooth muscle.defn: Muscle tissue consisting of sheets of mononucleated cells innervated by the autonomic nervous system.

sodium&#8211;potassium (Na<sup>+</sup>&#.defn: Anti-porter responsible for primary active transport; it pumps sodium ions out of the cell and potassium ions into the cell, both against their concentration gradients. Also called a sodium–potassium ATPase.

soil fertility.defn: The ability of a soil to sustain plant growth, in terms of the soil's concentration of available plant nutrients.

soil solution.defn: The aqueous portion of soil, from which plants take up dissolved mineral nutrients.

soils.defn: The upper layers of Earth's surface that support plant growth.

solute.defn: A substance that is dissolved in a liquid (solvent) to form a solution.

solute potential.defn: A property of any solution, resulting from its solute contents; it may be zero or have a negative value. The more negative the solute potential, the greater the tendency of the solution to take up water through a differentially permeable membrane.

solution.defn: A liquid (the solvent) and its dissolved solutes.

solvent.defn: Liquid in which a substance (solute) is dissolved to form a solution.

solvent drag.defn: Transport mechanism in which solutes move across a tissue layer through intercellular spaces by a flow of water (solvent).

somatic cell.defn: All the cells of the body that are not specialized for reproduction.

somatic cell gene therapy.defn: Alteration of the human genome sequence in somatic cells for medical benefit.

somatic mutation.defn: Permanent genetic change in a somatic cell (as opposed to a germ cell, the egg or sperm). These mutations affect the individual only; they are not passed on to offspring.

somatosensory cortex.defn: An area of the parietal lobe that receives touch and pressure information from mechanoreceptors throughout the body; neurons in this area are arranged according to the parts of the body with which they communicate.

somatostatin.defn: Peptide hormone made in the hypothalamus that inhibits the release of other hormones from the pituitary and intestine.

somite.defn: One of the segments into which an embryo becomes divided longitudinally, leading to the eventual segmentation of the animal as illustrated by the spinal column, ribs, and associated muscles.

soredia.defn: Propagules of lichens consisting of one or a few photosynthetic cells bound by fungal hyphae.

sorus.defn: A spore-producing structure on the underside of a fern frond.

source.defn: In plants, any organ that exports the products of photosynthesis in excess of its own needs, such as a mature leaf or storage organ.

source populations.defn: Populations that serve as a net source of individuals to other populations within a metapopulation.

spatial summation.defn: In the production or inhibition of action potentials in a postsynaptic cell, the interaction of depolarizations and hyperpolarizations produced at different sites on the postsynaptic cell.

speciation.defn: The process of splitting one population into two populations that are reproductively isolated from one another.

species.defn: "The base unit of taxonomic classification, consisting of an ancestor–descendant group of populations of evolutionarily closely related, similar organisms. The more narrowly defined ""biological species"" consists of individuals capable of interbreeding with each other but not with members of other species."

species composition.defn: The kinds of species present in a community.

species concepts.defn: The ways that biologists think about the category of species.

species diversity.defn: A measure that combines the number of species (species richness) in a community and their relative abundances compared with one another (species evenness).

species evenness.defn: The relative abundances of species compared to one another.

species richness.defn: The total number of species within an area.

species&#8211;area relationship.defn: The relationship between the size of an area and the numbers of species it supports.

specific heat.defn: The amount of energy that must be absorbed by a gram of a substance to raise its temperature by one degree centigrade. By convention, water is assigned a specific heat of one.

spermatid.defn: One of the products of the second meiotic division of a primary spermatocyte; four haploid spermatids, which remain connected by cytoplasmic bridges, are produced for each primary spermatocyte that enters meiosis.

spermatogonium.defn: In animals, the diploid progeny of a germ cell in males.

spherical symmetry.defn: The simplest form of symmetry, in which body parts radiate out from a central point such that an infinite number of planes passing through that central point can divide the organism into similar halves.

sphincter.defn: A ring of muscle that can close an orifice, for example, at the anus.

spicule.defn: A hard, calcareous skeletal element typical of sponges.

spinal reflex.defn: The conversion of afferent to efferent information in the spinal cord without participation of the brain.

spindle apparatus.defn: Array of microtubules emanating from both poles of a dividing cell during mitosis and playing a role in the movement of chromosomes at nuclear division.

spiral cleavage.defn: A form of complete cleavage in which the cleavage planes are at oblique angles to the animal-vegetal axis.

spleen.defn: Organ that serves as a reservoir for venous blood and eliminates old, damaged red blood cells from the circulation.

spontaneous generation.defn: The idea that under ordinary circumstances, living organisms can form from non-living materials.

spontaneous mutation.defn: A genetic change caused by internal cellular mechanisms, such as an error in DNA replication.

sporangiophore.defn: A stalked reproductive structure produced by zygospore fungi that extends from a hypha and bears one or many sporangia.

sporangium.defn: In plants and fungi, any specialized stucture within which one or more spores are formed.

spore.defn: (1) Any asexual reproductive cell capable of developing into an adult organism without gametic fusion. In plants, haploid spores develop into gametophytes, diploid spores into sporophytes. (2) In prokaryotes, a resistant cell capable of surviving unfavorable periods.

sporophyte.defn: In plants and protists with alternation of generations, the diploid phase that produces the spores.

sporulation.defn: The formation of spores, or resting stages.

stability.defn: The resistance of an ecological community to (or recovery from) a disturbance.

stabilizing selection.defn: Selection against the extreme phenotypes in a population, so that the intermediate types are favored.

stamen.defn: A male (pollen-producing) unit of a flower, usually composed of an anther, which bears the pollen, and a filament, which is a stalk supporting the anther.

standard deviation.defn: A measure of the spread of observations in a sample.

standard error.defn: A measure of how close a sample statistic (such as the mean) is likely to be to the true population value.

standard error of the mean.defn: A measure of how close a sample mean is likely to be to the true population value. Calculated by dividing the standard deviation of a sample by the square root of the sample size.

standard free energy.defn: The energy associated with a chemical reaction that can be used to do work. The sum of the enthalpy and the product of temperature and entropy.

starch.defn: A polymer of glucose; used by plants to store energy.

Starling's forces.defn: The two opposing forces responsible for water movement across capillary walls: blood pressure, which squeezes water and small solutes out of the capillaries, and osmotic pressure, which pulls water back into the capillaries.

start codon.defn: The mRNA triplet (AUG) that acts as a signal for the beginning of translation at the ribosome.

static life table.defn: A life table that records the survival and reproduction of individuals of different ages during a single time period.

statistic.defn: A numerical quantity calculated from data.

stele.defn: The central cylinder of vascular tissue in a plant stem.

stem.defn: In plants, the organ that holds leaves and/or flowers and transports and distributes materials among the other organs of the plant.

stem cell.defn: In animals, an undifferentiated cell that is capable of continuous proliferation. A stem cell generates more stem cells and a large clone of differentiated progeny cells.

stereocilia.defn: Fingerlike extensions of hair cell membranes whose bending initiates sound perception.

steroid hormones.defn: Steroid molecules that circulate in the blood and effect cells with appropriate receptors. Examples are testosterone and estrogen.

sticky ends.defn: On a piece of two-stranded DNA, short, complementary, one-stranded regions produced by the action of a restriction endonuclease. Sticky ends facilitate the joining of segments of DNA from different sources.

stigma.defn: The part of the pistil at the apex of the style that is receptive to pollen, and on which pollen germinates.

stock.defn: In horticulture, the root or root-bearing stem to which a bud or piece of stem from another plant (the scion) is grafted.

stoma.defn: Small opening in the plant epidermis that permits gas exchange; bounded by a pair of guard cells whose osmotic status regulates the size of the opening.

stomach.defn: An organ that physically (and sometimes enzymatically) breaks down food, preparing it for digestion in the midgut.

stomatal crypt.defn: In plants, a sunken cavity below the leaf surface in which a stoma is sheltered from the drying effects of air currents.

stop codon.defn: Any of the three mRNA codons that signal the end of protein translation at the ribosome: UAG, UGA, UAA.

stratum.defn: A layer of rock laid down at a particular time in the past.

stress.defn: An abiotic factor that reduces the growth, reproduction, and/or the survival of some individuals.

stretch receptor.defn: A modified muscle cell embedded in the connective tissue of a muscle that acts as a mechanoreceptor in response to stretching of that muscle.

strigolactones.defn: Signaling molecules produced by plant roots that attract the hyphae of mycorrhizal fungi.

strobilus.defn: One of several conelike structures in various groups of plants (including club mosses, horsetails, and conifers) associated with the production and dispersal of reproductive products.

stroke.defn: An embolism in an artery in the brain that causes the cells fed by that artery to die. The specific damage, such as memory loss, speech impairment, or paralysis, depends on the location of the blocked artery.

structural gene.defn: A gene that encodes the primary structure of a protein not involved in the regulation of gene expression.

structural isomers.defn: Molecules made up of the same kinds and numbers of atoms, in which the atoms are bonded differently.

structural motif.defn: A three-dimensional structural element that is part of a larger molecule. For example, there are four common motifs in DNA-binding proteins: helix-turn-helix, zinc finger, leucine zipper, and helix-loop-helix.

style.defn: In the angiosperm flower, a column of tissue extending from the tip of the ovary, and bearing the stigma or receptive surface for pollen at its apex.

subduction.defn: In plate tectonics, the movement of one lithospheric plate under another.

submucosa.defn: The tissue layer just under the epithelial lining of the lumen of the digestive tract.

subsoil.defn: The soil horizon lying below the topsoil and above the parent rock (bedrock); the zone of infiltration and accumulation of materials leached from the topsoil. Also called the B horizon.

substrate.defn: (1) The molecule or molecules on which an enzyme exerts catalytic action. (2) The base material on which a sessile organism lives.

succession.defn: The gradual, sequential series of changes in the species composition of an ecological community following a disturbance.

succulence.defn: In plants, possession of fleshy, water-storing leaves or stems; an adaptation to dry environments.

sulci.defn: The valleys between the folds of the cerebral cortex.

superficial cleavage.defn: A variation of incomplete cleavage in which cycles of mitosis occur without cell division, producing a syncytium (a single cell with many nuclei).

superior vena cava.defn: Large vein that returns deoxygenated blood to the right atrium from the upper body.

suprachiasmatic nuclei.defn: In mammals, two clusters of neurons just above the optic chiasm that act as the master circadian clock.

surface area-to-volume ratio.defn: For any cell, organism, or geometrical solid, the ratio of surface area to volume; this is an important factor in setting an upper limit on the size a cell or organism can attain.

surface tension.defn: The attractive intermolecular forces at the surface of liquid; an especially important property of water.

surfactant.defn: A substance that decreases the surface tension of a liquid. Lung surfactant, secreted by cells of the alveoli, is mostly phospholipid and decreases the amount of work necessary to inflate the lungs.

survivorship.defn: The fraction of individuals that survive from birth to a given life stage or age.

survivorship curve.defn: A plot of the number of individuals surviving through each life stage (survivorship, l<sub>x</sub>) for a hypothetical cohort, usually of 1,000 individuals; includes three general curves called type I, II, and III.

suspension feeders.defn: An organism that feeds on organisms much smaller than itself that are suspended in water or air by means of a straining device. Also called filter feeder.

suspensor.defn: In the embryos of seed plants, the stalk of cells that pushes the embryo into the endosperm and is a source of nutrient transport to the embryo.

sustainable.defn: Pertaining to the use and management of ecosystems in such a way that humans benefit over the long term from specific ecosystem goods and services without compromising others.

swim bladder.defn: An organ used primarily to regulate buoyancy in fish.

symbiosis.defn: The living together of two or more species in a prolonged and intimate relationship.

symbiotic.defn: A relationship in which two or more organisms live in close association with one another.

symmetry.defn: Pertaining to an attribute of an animal body in which at least one plane can divide the body into similar, mirror-image halves.

sympathetic nervous system.defn: The division of the autonomic nervous system that works in opposition to the parasympathetic nervous system.

sympatric speciation.defn: Speciation due to reproductive isolation without any physical separation of the subpopulation.

symplast.defn: The continuous meshwork of the interiors of living cells in the plant body, resulting from the presence of plasmodesmata.

symporter.defn: A membrane transport protein that carries two substances in the same direction.

synapomorphy.defn: A trait that arose in the ancestor of a phylogenetic group and is present (sometimes in modified form) in all of its members, thus helping to delimit and identify that group. Also called a shared derived trait.

synapse.defn: A specialized type of junction where a neuron meets its target cell (which can be another neuron or some other type of cell) and information in the form of neurotransmitter molecules is exchanged across a synaptic cleft.

synapsis.defn: The highly specific parallel alignment (pairing) of homologous chromosomes during the first division of meiosis.

synaptic cleft.defn: The space between the presynaptic cell and the postsynaptic cell in a chemical synapse.

syncytium.defn: A single cell with many nuclei produced as a result of superficial cleavage.

synonymous (silent) substitution.defn: A change of one nucleotide in a sequence to another when that change does not affect the amino acid specified (i.e., UUA → UUG, both specifying leucine).

systematics.defn: The scientific study of the diversity and relationships among organisms.

systemic acquired resistance.defn: A general resistance to many plant pathogens following infection by a single agent.

systemic circuit.defn: Portion of the circulatory system by which oxygenated blood from the lungs or gills is distributed throughout the rest of the body and returned to the heart.

systems biology.defn: The scientific study of an organism as an integrated and interacting system of genes, proteins, and biochemical reactions.

systole.defn: Contraction of a chamber of the heart, driving blood forward in the circulatory system.

T cell.defn: A type of lymphocyte involved in the cellular immune response. The final stages of its development occur in the thymus gland.

T cell receptor.defn: A protein on the surface of a T cell that recognizes the antigenic determinant for which the cell is specific.

T tubules.defn: A system of tubules that runs throughout the cytoplasm of a muscle fiber, through which action potentials spread.

T-helper (T<sub>H</sub>) cell.defn: Type of T cell that stimulates events in both the cellular and humoral immune responses by binding to the antigen on an antigen-presenting cell; target of the HIV-I virus, the agent of AIDS.

taproot.defn: The largest plant root from which other roots sprout laterally.

taproot system.defn: A root system typical of eudicots consisting of a primary root (taproot) that extends downward by tip growth and outward by initiating lateral roots.

taste bud.defn: A structure in the epithelium of the tongue that includes a cluster of chemoreceptors innervated by sensory neurons.

TATA box.defn: An eight-base-pair sequence, found about 25 base pairs before the starting point for transcription in many eukaryotic promoters, that binds a transcription factor and thus helps initiate transcription.

taxon.defn: A biological group (typically a species or a clade) that is given a name.

telencephalon.defn: The outer, surrounding structure of the embryonic vertebrate forebrain, which develops into the cerebrum.

telomerase.defn: An enzyme that catalyzes the addition of telomeric sequences lost from chromosomes during DNA replication.

telomeres.defn: Repeated DNA sequences at the ends of eukaryotic chromosomes.

temperature inversions.defn: Foggy conditions created when cold air is trapped within a warm inversion layer that forms over valleys during warm days.

template.defn: A molecule or surface on which another molecule is synthesized in complementary fashion, as in the replication of DNA.

temporal lobe.defn: One of the four lobes of the cerebral hemisphere; receives and processes auditory and visual information; involved in recognizing, identifying, and naming objects.

temporal summation.defn: In the production or inhibition of action potentials in a postsynaptic cell, the interaction of depolarizations or hyperpolarizations produced by rapidly repeated stimulation of a single point on the postsynaptic cell.

tendon.defn: A collagen-containing band of tissue that connects a muscle with a bone.

terminal bud.defn: Growing point at the end of a plant stem or branch.

termination.defn: In molecular biology, the end of transcription or translation.

territorial behavior.defn: Aggressive actions engaged in to defend a habitat or resource such that other animals are denied access.

tertiary endosymbiosis.defn: The mechanism by which some eukaryotes acquired the capacity for photosynthesis; for example, a dinoflagellate that apparently lost its chloroplast became photosynthetic by engulfing another protist that had acquired a chloroplast through secondary endosymbiosis.

tertiary structure.defn: In reference to a protein, the relative locations in three-dimensional space of all the atoms in the molecule. The overall shape of a protein.

test cross.defn: Mating of a dominant-phenotype individual (who may be either heterozygous or homozygous) with a homozygous-recessive individual.

testis.defn: The male gonad; the organ that produces the male gametes.

tetanus.defn: "(1) A state of sustained maximal muscular contraction caused by rapidly repeated stimulation. (2) In medicine, an often fatal disease (""lockjaw"") caused by the bacterium Clostridium tetani."

tetrad.defn: During prophase I of meiosis, the association of a pair of homologous chromosomes or four chromatids.

thalamus.defn: A region of the vertebrate forebrain; involved in integration of sensory input.

thallus.defn: The body of a fungus or plant that is not differentiated into stem and leaves and lacks true roots and a vascular system.

thecal cells.defn: Cells of the ovarian follicle of mammals that bound the follicle and secrete the hormone testosterone.

theory.defn: A far-reaching explanation of observed facts that is supported by such a wide body of evidence, with no significant contradictory evidence, that it is scientifically accepted as a factual framework. Examples are Newton's theory of gravity and Darwin's theory of evolution.

theory of island biogeography.defn: A theory proposing that the number of species on an island (or in another geographically defined and isolated area) represents a balance, or equilibrium, between the rate at which species immigrate to the island and the rate at which resident species go extinct.

thermogenin.defn: Also called Uncoupling Protein 1 (UPC1). A protein in the mitochondria of brown fat that uncouples oxidative phosphorylation.

thermoneutral zone.defn: The range of temperatures over which an endotherm does not have to expend extra energy to thermoregulate.

thermoregulatory adaptations.defn: Physiological and behavioral mechanisms for altering the heat content of the body.

thoracic cavity.defn: The portion of the mammalian body cavity bounded by the ribs, shoulders, and diaphragm. Contains the heart and the lungs.

thoracic duct.defn: The connection between the lymphatic system and the circulatory system.

threshold.defn: The level of depolarization that causes an electrically excitable membrane to fire an action potential.

thrombin.defn: An enzyme involved in blood clotting; cleaves fibrinogen to form fibrin.

thrombus.defn: A blood clot that forms within a blood vessel and remains attached to the wall of the vessel.

thylakoid.defn: A flattened sac within a chloroplast. Thylakoid membranes contain all of the chlorophyll in a plant, in addition to the electron carriers of photophosphorylation. Thylakoids stack to form grana.

thyroid gland.defn: A two-lobed gland in vertebrates. Produces the hormone thyroxine.

thyroid-stimulating hormone.defn: Hormone produced by the anterior pituitary that stimulates the thyroid gland to produce and release thyroxine. Also called thyrotropin.

thyrotropin.defn: Hormone produced by the anterior pituitary that stimulates the thyroid gland to produce and release thyroxine. Also called thyroid-stimulating hormone (TSH).

thyrotropin-releasing hormone.defn: Hormone produced by the hypothalamus that stimulates the anterior pituitary to release thyrotropin.

thyroxine.defn: Hormone produced by the thyroid gland; controls many metabolic processes.

tidal.defn: The bidirectional form of ventilation used by all vertebrates except birds; air enters and leaves the lungs by the same route.

tidal volume.defn: The volume of air inhaled and exhaled by a resting individual.

tight junction.defn: A junction between epithelial cells in which there is no gap between adjacent cells.

tissue.defn: A group of similar cells organized into a functional unit; usually integrated with other tissues to form part of an organ.

titin.defn: A protein that holds bundles of myosin filaments in a centered position within the sarcomeres of muscle cells. The largest protein in the human body.

Toll-like receptors.defn: Membrane proteins of macrophages and dendritic cells with extracellular domains that recognize molecules from microbial pathogens.

tonoplast.defn: The membrane of the plant central vacuole.

topography.defn: The shape and surface features of Earth, in the form of mountains, valleys, ocean basins, etc.

topsoil.defn: The uppermost soil horizon; contains most of the organic matter of soil, but may be depleted of most mineral nutrients by leaching. Also called the A horizon.

totipotent.defn: Possessing all the genetic information and other capacities necessary to form an entire individual.

trachea.defn: A tube that carries air to the bronchi of the lungs of vertebrates. When plural(tracheae), refers to the major airways of insects.

tracheary element.defn: Either of two types of xylem cells—tracheids and vessel elements—that undergo apoptosis before assuming their transport function.

tracheid.defn: A type of tracheary element found in the xylem of nearly all vascular plants, characterized by tapering ends and walls that are pitted but not perforated.

trade winds.defn: Prevailing winds that blow from east to west across the tropics.

trade-off.defn: The relationship between the fitness benefits conferred by an adaptation and the fitness costs it imposes. For an adaptation to be favored by natural selection, the benefits must exceed the costs.

trait.defn: In genetics, a specific form of a character: eye color is a character; brown eyes and blue eyes are traits.

transcription.defn: The synthesis of RNA using one strand of DNA as a template.

transcription factors.defn: Proteins that assemble on a eukaryotic chromosome, allowing RNA polymerase II to perform transcription.

transect.defn: A linear measurement of any length used to count individuals along the stretch of the line.

transfection.defn: Insertion of recombinant DNA into animal cells.

transfer RNA.defn: A family of folded RNA molecules. Each tRNA carries a specific amino acid and anticodon that will pair with the complementary codon in mRNA during translation.

transformation.defn: (1) A mechanism for transfer of genetic information in bacteria in which pure DNA from a bacterium of one genotype is taken in through the cell surface of a bacterium of a different genotype and incorporated into the chromosome of the recipient cell. (2) Insertion of recombinant DNA into a host cell.

transgenic.defn: Containing recombinant DNA incorporated into the genetic material.

transition.defn: In genetics, a mutation such that a purine base is converted to the other purine (e.g., adenine to guanine) or a pyrimidine to the other pyrimidine (e.g., C to T)

transition state.defn: In an enzyme-catalyzed reaction, the reactive condition of the substrate after there has been sufficient input of energy (activation energy) to initiate the reaction.

transition-state intermediate.defn: Unstable molecule in a reaction which is formed during the reaction when reactants change into products.

translation.defn: The synthesis of a protein (polypeptide). Takes place on ribosomes, using the information encoded in messenger RNA.

translocation.defn: (1) In genetics, a rare mutational event that moves a portion of a chromosome to a new location, generally on a nonhomologous chromosome. (2) In vascular plants, movement of solutes in the phloem.

transmembrane domain.defn: A protein region rich in hydrophobic amino acids that spans the phospholipid bilayer.

transmembrane protein.defn: An integral membrane protein that spans the phospholipid bilayer.

transpiration.defn: The evaporation of water from plant leaves and stem, driven by heat from the sun, and providing the motive force to raise water (plus mineral nutrients) from the roots.

transposable element.defn: A segment of DNA that can move to, or give rise to copies at, another locus on the same or a different chromosome.

transversion.defn: A mutation that changes a purine to a pyrimidine or vice versa.

tree of life.defn: A term that encompasses the evolutionary history of all life, or a graphic representation of that history.

tricuspid valve.defn: The right AV valve. So named because it has three leaves.

triglyceride.defn: A simple lipid in which three fatty acids are combined with one molecule of glycerol.

trimesters.defn: The three stages of human pregnancy, approximately 3 months each in length.

tripartite synapse.defn: The idea that a synapse includes not only the pre- and postsynaptic neurons involved but also encompasses many connections with glial cells called astrocytes.

triploblastic.defn: Having a body derived from three embryonic cell layers (ectoderm, mesoderm, and endoderm).

triploid (3n) cell.defn: A cell containing three sets of an organism's chromosomes.

trisomic.defn: Containing three rather than two members of a chromosome pair.

trochophore.defn: A radially symmetrical larval form typical of annelids and mollusks, distinguished by a wheel-like band of cilia around the middle.

trophic.defn: The feeding relationship between two or more species.

trophic cascade.defn: A series of trophic interactions within a food web in which the rate of consumption at one trophic level results in the change in species abundance or composition at lower trophic levels.

trophic efficiency.defn: A measure of the amount of energy or biomass at one trophic level divided by the amount of energy at the trophic level immediately below it.

trophic level.defn: A subdivision of a food web that includes species that have similar ways of interacting and obtaining energy.

trophoblast.defn: At the 32-cell stage of mammalian development, the outer group of cells that will become part of the placenta and thus nourish the growing embryo.

tropic hormones.defn: Hormones produced by the anterior pituitary that control the secretion of hormones by other endocrine glands.

tropomyosin.defn: One of the three protein components of an actin filament; controls the interactions of actin and myosin necessary for muscle contraction.

troponin.defn: One of the three components of an actin filament; binds to actin, tropomyosin, and Ca<sup>2+</sup>.

trypsin.defn: A protein-digesting enzyme. Secreted by the pancreas in its inactive form (trypsinogen), it becomes active in the duodenum of the small intestine.

tube feet.defn: A unique feature of echinoderms; extensions of the water vascular system, which functions in gas exchange, locomotion, and feeding.

tubulin.defn: A protein that polymerizes to form microtubules.

tumor.defn: A disorganized mass of cells. Malignant tumors spread to other parts of the body.

tumor necrosis factor.defn: A family of cytokines (growth factors) that causes cell death and is involved in inflammation.

tumor suppressor.defn: A gene that codes for a protein product that inhibits cell proliferation; inactive in cancer cells.

turgid.defn: Swollen or distended. In plants, a cell is turgid when its water potential is lower than that of the surrounding environment.

turgor pressure.defn: The force exerted by a plant cell against the cell wall when it has taken up water by osmosis.

twitch.defn: A muscle fiber's minimum unit of contraction, stimulated by a single action potential.

Type I error.defn: The incorrect rejection of a true null hypothesis.

type I survivorship curve.defn: A survivorship curve in which individuals experience high overall survivorship through adulthood but a steep decline late in life.

Type II error.defn: The incorrect acceptance of a false null hypothesis.

type II survivorship curves.defn: A survivorship curve in which individuals experience a constant chance of surviving at all ages.

type III survivorship curve.defn: A survivorship curve in which individuals experience low survivorship early in life and higher survivorship once they reach maturity.

ubiquitin.defn: A small protein that is covalently linked to other cellular proteins identified for breakdown by the proteosome.

ultimate causes.defn: In ethology, the evolutionary processes that produce an animal's capacity and tendency to behave in particular ways.

uncompetitive inhibitor.defn: An enzyme inhibitor that binds to the enzyme-substrate complex.

unequal crossing over.defn: When a highly repeated gene sequence becomes displaced in alignment during meiotic crossing over, so that one chromosome receives many copies of the sequence while the second chromosome receives fewer copies. One of the mechanisms of concerted evolution.

uniporter.defn: A membrane transport protein that carries a single substance in one direction.

unipotent.defn: An undifferentiated cell that is capable of becoming only one type of mature cell.

unloading.defn: In phloem, the process of transferring sugars and other molecules in phloem to adjacent plant tissues.

unsaturated fatty acid.defn: A fatty acid whose hydrocarbon chain contains one or more double bonds.

upper critical temperature.defn: The environmental temperature at which a resting endotherm must actively increase its heat loss to avoid a rise in its body temperature.

upwelling.defn: A process by which offshore winds in combination with the Coriolis effect push warmer surface water away from the shore, allowing cold, nutrient-rich water from deeper waters to rise to the surface.

uracil.defn: A pyrimidine base found in nucleotides of RNA.

urea.defn: A compound that is the main form of nitrogen excreted by many animals, including mammals.

ureotelic.defn: Pertaining to an organism in which the final product of the breakdown of nitrogen-containing compounds (primarily proteins) is urea.

ureter.defn: Long duct leading from the vertebrate kidney to the urinary bladder or the cloaca.

urethra.defn: In most mammals, the canal through which urine is discharged from the bladder and which serves as the genital duct in males.

uric acid.defn: A compound that serves as the main excreted form of nitrogen in some animals, particularly those which must conserve water, such as birds, insects, and reptiles.

uricotelic.defn: Pertaining to an organism in which the final product of the breakdown of nitrogen-containing compounds (primarily proteins) is uric acid.

urinary bladder.defn: A structure in which urine is stored until it can be excreted to the outside of the body.

urine.defn: In vertebrates, the fluid waste product containing the toxic nitrogenous by-products of protein and nucleic acid metabolism.

uterine cycle.defn: In human females, the monthly cycle of events by which the endometrium is prepared for the arrival of a blastocyst.

uterus.defn: A specialized portion of the female reproductive tract in mammals that receives the fertilized egg and nurtures the embryo in its early development. Also called the womb.

vaccination.defn: Injection of virus or bacteria or their proteins into the body, to induce immunity. The injected material is usually attenuated (weakened) before injection and is called a vaccine.

vacuole.defn: Membrane-enclosed organelle in plant cells that can function for storage, water concentration for turgor, or hydrolysis of stored macromolecules.

vagina.defn: In female animals, the entry to the reproductive tract.

valence shell.defn: The outermost energy shell of an atom, containing the valence electrons involved in chemical reactivity.

van der Waals forces.defn: Weak attractions between atoms resulting from the interaction of the electrons of one atom with the nucleus of another. This type of attraction is about one-fourth as strong as a hydrogen bond.

variable region.defn: The portion of an immunoglobulin molecule or T cell receptor that includes the antigen-binding site and is responsible for its specificity.

vas deferens.defn: Duct that transfers sperm from the epididymis to the urethra.

vasa recta.defn: Blood vessels that parallel the loops of Henle and the collecting ducts in the renal medulla of the kidney.

vascular bundle.defn: In vascular plants, a strand of vascular tissue, including xylem and phloem as well as thick-walled fibers.

vascular cambium.defn: In plants, a lateral meristem that gives rise to secondary xylem and phloem.

vascular tissue system.defn: The transport system of a vascular plant, consisting primarily of xylem and phloem.

vasopressin.defn: A hormone that promotes water reabsorption by the kidney. Produced by neurons in the hypothalamus and released from nerve terminals in the posterior pituitary. Also called antidiuretic hormone or ADH.

vector.defn: (1) An agent, such as an insect, that carries a pathogen affecting another species. (2) A plasmid or virus that carries an inserted piece of DNA into a bacterium for cloning purposes in recombinant DNA technology.

vegetal hemisphere.defn: The lower portion of some animal eggs, zygotes, and embryos, in which the dense nutrient yolk settles. The vegetal pole is to the very bottom of the egg or embryo.

vegetal pole.defn: The point at the end of the developing egg where yolk is most concentrated.

vegetative meristem.defn: An apical meristem that produces leaves.

vegetative reproduction.defn: Asexual reproduction through the modification of stems, leaves, or roots.

vein.defn: A blood vessel that returns blood to the heart.

ventral.defn: Toward or pertaining to the belly or lower side.

ventricle.defn: A muscular heart chamber that pumps blood through the lungs or through the body.

venule.defn: A small blood vessel draining a capillary bed that joins others of its kind to form a vein.

vernalization.defn: Events occurring during a required chilling period, leading eventually to flowering.

vertebral column.defn: The jointed, dorsal column that is the primary support structure of vertebrates.

very low-density lipoproteins.defn: Lipoproteins that consist mainly of triglyceride fats, which they transport to fat cells in adipose tissues throughout the body; associated with excessive fat deposition and high risk for cardiovascular disease.

vessel element.defn: A type of tracheary element with perforated end walls; found only in angiosperms.

vestibular system.defn: Structures within the inner ear that sense changes in position or momentum of the head, affecting balance and motor skills.

vestibule.defn: A central part of the inner ear involved in balance.

vicariance.defn: The evolutionary separation of species due to a barrier that results in the geographic isolation of species that once were connected to one another.

villi.defn: Hairlike projections from a membrane; for example, from many gut walls.

virion.defn: The virus particle, the minimum unit capable of infecting a cell.

virus.defn: Any of a group of ultramicroscopic particles constructed of nucleic acid and protein (and, sometimes, lipid) that require living cells in order to reproduce. Viruses evolved multiple times from different cellular species.

visceral mass.defn: The bulk of the digestive, reproductive, excretory, and respiratory systems of mollusks, contained within the shell.

vital capacity.defn: The maximum capacity for air exchange in one breath; the sum of the tidal volume and the inspiratory and expiratory reserve volumes.

vitamin.defn: An organic compound that an organism cannot synthesize, but nevertheless requires in small quantities for normal growth and metabolism.

vitelline envelope.defn: The inner, proteinaceous protective layer of a sea urchin egg.

viviparity.defn: Reproduction in which fertilization of the egg and development of the embryo occur inside the mother's body.

voltage.defn: A measure of the difference in electrical charge between two points.

voltage-gated channel.defn: A type of gated channel that opens or closes when a certain voltage exists across the membrane in which it is inserted.

vomeronasal organ.defn: Chemosensory structure embedded in the nasal epithelium of amphibians, reptiles, and many mammals. Often specialized for detecting pheromones.

waggle dance.defn: A behavior of honeybees that communicates the direction and distance to a food source or a location for a new colony.

Walter climate diagram.defn: A graphic technique that plots temperature and precipitation data to visualize a growing season for plants (those months when average temperatures are above freezing and average precipitation is sufficient for plant growth).

warning signal.defn: A visual or acoustical defense mechanism used by prey species to advertise to predators that they may be toxic.

water potential.defn: In osmosis, the tendency for a system (a cell or solution) to take up water from pure water through a differentially permeable membrane.

water vascular system.defn: In echinoderms, a network of water-filled canals that functions in gas exchange, locomotion, and feeding.

wavelength.defn: The distance between successive peaks of a wave train, such as electromagnetic radiation.

weather.defn: The short-term state of atmospheric conditions (temperature, precipitation, humidity, wind direction and velocity) at a particular place and time.

weathered.defn: The mechanical and chemical processes by which rocks are broken down into soil particles.

Wernicke's area.defn: A region in the temporal lobe of the human brain that is involved with the sensory aspects of language.

westerlies.defn: Prevailing winds that blow from west to east across the mid-latitudes.

white blood cells.defn: Cells in the blood plasma that play defensive roles in the immune system. Also called leukocytes.

white matter.defn: In the central nervous system, tissue that is rich in axons.

wild type.defn: Geneticists' term for standard or reference type. Deviants from this standard, even if the deviants are found in the wild, are usually referred to as mutant. (Note that this terminology is not usually applied to human genes.)

xerophyte.defn: A plant adapted to an environment with limited water supply.

xylem.defn: In vascular plants, the tissue that conducts water and minerals; xylem consists, in various plants, of tracheids, vessel elements, fibers, and other highly specialized cells.

xylem sap.defn: The liquid contents of the xylem.

xylem vessels.defn: Continuous tubes that conduct water in plants.

yeasts.defn: Microscopic fungi consisting of single oval cells that reproduce by budding.

yolk.defn: The stored food material in animal eggs, rich in protein and lipids.

yolk sac.defn: In reptiles, birds, and mammals, the extraembryonic membrane that forms from the endoderm of the hypoblast; it encloses and digests the yolk.

zeatin.defn: A cytokinin originally purified from corn kernels.

zeaxanthin.defn: A blue-light receptor involved in the opening of plant stomata.

zona pellucida.defn: A jellylike substance that surrounds the mammalian ovum when it is released from the ovary.

zone of cell division.defn: The apical and primary meristems of a plant root; the source of all cells of the root's primary tissues.

zone of cell elongation.defn: The part of a plant root, generally above the zone of cell division, where cells are expanding (growing), primarily in the longitudinal direction.

zone of maturation.defn: The part of a plant root, generally above the zone of cell elongation, where cells are differentiating.

zygospore.defn: Multinucleate, diploid cell that is a resting stage in the life cycle of zygospore fungi.

zygote.defn: The cell created by the union of two gametes, in which the gamete nuclei are also fused. The earliest stage of the diploid generation.

zymogen.defn: The inactive precursor of a digestive enzyme; secreted into the lumen of the gut, where a protease cleaves it to form the active enzyme.
